GENERAL:
1988 Term closed and 1989 Term convened October 2, 1989;
adjourned October 1, 1990.
Blackmun, J., assigned as Circuit Justice for 1st Circuit
pending further order.
Brennan, J., announces retirement on Friday, July 20,
1990, effective that date.
Chief Justice assigned as Circuit Justice for 1st and 3rd
Circuit, effective July 20, 1990 pending further order;
order vacated.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, OCTOBER 2, 1989
1
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"I have the honor to announce, on behalf of the Court, that the Octo-
ber 1988 Term of the Supreme Court of the United States is now closed
and that the October 1989 Term is now convened. Today's orders of the
Court have been certified by the Chief Justice, filed with the Clerk, and
will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 88-1891. M & M Construction Company, Inc., Appellant v. Great
American Insurance Company. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of
Texas, Thirteenth District. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdic-
tion. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition
for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 88-7460. Owen W. Crumpacker, Appellant v. Indiana, et al. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of Indiana. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken
as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 88-1770. Westinghouse Electric Corporation, Petitioner v.
Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. On petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit.
The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated
and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Third Circuit for further consideration in light of Public Employees
Retirement System of Ohio v. Betts, 492 U. S. — (1989).
No. 88-2034. George F. Denton, et al., Petitioners v. Mike Her-
nandez. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The motion of respondent for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The petition for writ of certiorari
is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of Neitzke v. Williams, 490 U. S. — (1989).

2
MONDAY, OCTOBER 2, 1989
No. 88-7343. Forrest G. English, et al., Petitioners v. Donald
Siddens, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States.
Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. The motion of petitioners
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for writ of cer-
tiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit for fur-
ther consideration in light of Reed v. United Transporation Union, 488
U. S. (1989).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. Robert V. Posey, Petitioner v. Department of the Air
Force. The motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ of cer-
tiorari, out-of-time, is denied.
No. Abraham T. Yang, Petitioner v. Daniel J. McCarthy. The
motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ of certiorari, out-
of-time, is denied.
No. 65, Original. State of Texas, Plaintiff v. State of New Mexico.
The motion of the River Master for approval of fees and expenses is
granted and the River Master is awarded $4,313.43 for the period April
1 - June 30, 1989, to be paid equally by the parties.
No. 74, Original. State of Georgia, Plaintiff v. State of South Caro-
lina. The Exceptions to the Report of the Special Master are set for oral
argument in due course.
No. 87-1387. Wards Cove Packing Company, Inc., et al., Petitioners
v. Frank Atonio, et al. The motion of respondents to retax costs is
denied.
No. 87-2048. Texaco, Inc., Petitioner v. Ricky Hasbrouck, dba
Rick's Texaco, et al. The motion of National Coalition of Petroleum
Retailers for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted.
No. 88-790. Bernard J. Turnock, et al., Appellants v. Richard M.
Ragsdale, et al. The motion of Alan Ernest for leave to represent chil-
dren unborn and born alive is denied. The motion of Legal Defense for
Unborn Children for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is denied. The
motion of Larry Joyce for leave to participate in oral argument as
amicus curiae, for divided argument and for additional time for oral
argument is denied. Justice Stevens took no part in the consideration or
decision of these motions.
No. 88-805. Ohio, Appellant v. Akron Center for Reproductive
Health, et al. The motion of Alan Ernest for leave to represent children
unborn and born alive is denied. The motion of Legal Defense for Un-

MONDAY, OCTOBER 2, 1989
3
born Children for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is denied. The
motion of James Joseph Lynch, Jr., for leave to file a brief as amicus
curiae is denied.
No. 88-870. Nicholas Longo and Edward Fagan, Petitioners v.
United States, et al. The motion of petitioners for leave to file a reply
brief, out-of-time, is granted.
No. 88-931. Lawrence H. Crandon, et al, Petitioners v. United
States; and
No. 88-938. Boeing Company, Inc., Petitioner v. United States. The
motion of petitioners for divided argument is granted.
No. 88-1125. Jane Hodgson, et al, Petitioners v. Minnesota, et al.
The motion of Alan Ernest for leave to represent children unborn and
born alive is denied. The motion of Legal Defense for Unborn Children
for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is denied.
No. 88-1400. Franchise Tax Board of California, et al., Petitioners v.
Alcan Aluminium Limited, et al. The motion of respondents for divided
argument is denied.
No. 88-1474. United States, Petitioner 2. Goodyear Tire and Rubber
Company and Affiliates. The motion of Vulcan Materials Company for
leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted.
No. 88-1775, Gary E. Peel, Petitioner v. Attorney Registration and
Disciplinary Commission of Illinois. The motion of Academy of Certified
Trial Lawyers of Minnesota for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae
is granted. The motion of American Advertising Federation, Inc. for
leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The motion of Public
Citizen for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The motion.
of Association of Trial Lawyers of America, et al. for leave to file a brief
as amici curiae is granted. The motion of Association of National Ad-
vertisers, Inc. for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The
motion of Washington Legal Foundation, et al. for leave to file a brief as
amici curiae is granted.
No. 88-1958. Supreme Beef Processors, Inc., Petitioner 1. Robert
Yaquinto, Jr., etc. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this
case expressing the views of the United States.
No. 88-2009. Altheus Richardson, et al., Petitioners v. United Steel
Workers of America. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in
this case expressing the views of the United States.
No. 88-2041. Everett A. Sisson, Petitioner v. Burton B. Ruby, et al.
The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this case expressing the
views of the United States.

4
MONDAY, OCTOBER 2, 1989
No. 88-2062. Patricia Cotton, etc., Petitioner v. Patrick Babcock,
Director, Michigan Department of Social Services. The Solicitor Gen-
eral is invited to file a brief in this case expressing the views of the
United States.
No. 88-2109. Kansas and Missouri, etc. Petitioners v. Kansas Power
& Light Company, et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in
this case expressing the views of the United States.
No. 88-2117. Income Security Corporation, Inc., et al., Petitioners v.
Louisiana Oilfield Contractors Association, Inc. et al. The Solicitor
General is invited to file a brief in this case expressing the views of the
United States.
No. 89-46. Patricia M. Wood, et al., Petitioners v. General Motors.
Corporation. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this case.
expressing the views of the United States.
No. 89-56. Nancy Allevato, Personal Representative of the Estate of
Michael J. Ferrantino, Sr., Deceased, et al., Petitioners v. Counties of
Oakland and Macomb, Michigan;
No. 89-79. City of Detroit, Petitioner v. County of Oakland and
County of Macomb; and
No. 89–101. Coleman A. Young, Mayor of the City of Detroit, Peti-
tioner v. Counties of Oakland and Macomb. The Solicitor General is
invited to file a brief in these cases expressing the views of the United
States.
No. 88-6075. Darryl James, Petitioner v. Illinois. The motion of peti-
tioner for leave to file a reply brief, out of-time, is granted.
No. 88-7146. Jonas H. Whitmore, individually and as next friend of
Ronald Gene Simmons, Petitioner v. Arkansas, et al. The motion for
appointment of counsel is granted and it is ordered that Arthur L. Al-
len, Esquire, of Little Rock, Arkansas, is appointed to serve as counsel
for the petitioner in this case.
No. 88-7309. Kathy Nollsch, Petitioner v. Wyoming. The motion of
petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner
is allowed until October 23, 1989, within which to pay the docketing fee
required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a petition in compliance with Rule
33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall, Justice
Blackmun and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the reasons expressed
in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U. S. 928 (1983), we would deny the
petition for a writ of certiorari without reaching the merits of the
motion to proceed in forma pauperis.

MONDAY, OCTOBER 2. 1989
5
No. 88-7487. Juergen Stengel, Petitioner v. California. The motion of
petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner
is allowed until October 23, 1989, within which to pay the docketing fee
required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a petition in compliance with Rule
33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall, Justice
Blackmun and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the reasons expressed
in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U. S. 928 (1983), we would deny the
petition for a writ of certiorari without reaching the merits of the
motion to proceed in forma pauperis.
No. 88-7322. Karl Stumpf, Petitioner v. Commissioner, Internal
Revenue Service. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until October 23, 1989,
within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to
submit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court.
Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For
the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U. S. 928
(1983), we would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari without
reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.
No. 88-7356. John C. Carr, Petitioner v. United States. The motion
of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied. Peti-
tioner is allowed until October 23, 1989, within which to pay the
docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a petition in compli-
ance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan, Justice
Marshall and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in
Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U. S. 928 (1983), we would deny the
petition for a writ of certiorari without reaching the merits of the
motion to proceed in forma pauperis.
No. 88-7583. Ronald J. Roche, Petitioner v. United States Postal
Service. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma paupe-
ris is denied. Petitioner is allowed until October 23, 1989, within which
to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a petition
in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan,
Justice Marshall and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the reasons
expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U. S. 928 (1983), we would
deny the petition for a writ of certiorari without reaching the merits of
the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.
No. 88-7381. William George Bonin, Petitioner v. California. The
motion of petitioner for leave to file an amendment to the petition for a
writ of certiorari is granted.

6
MONDAY, OCTOBER 2, 1989
No. 88-7626. Juan Bautista Rivera, Petitioner. Oroweat Foods.
Company, Inc., et al. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until October 23, 1989,
within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to sub-
mit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court.
Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall, dissenting: For the reasons ex-
pressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U. S. 928 (1983), we would
deny the petition for a writ of certiorari without reaching the merits of
the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.
No. 89-5159. Thomas J. Malone, Petitioner v. Shelby County Board
of Education, et al. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until October 23, 1989,
within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to sub-
mit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court.
Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall, dissenting: For the reasons ex-
pressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U. S. 928 (1983), we would
deny the petition for a writ of certiorari without reaching the merits of
the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.
No. 89-5333. Felton Joshua, Sr., et ux., Petitioners v. Sally N. New-
ell, Foster Home Licensor, Department of Social and Health Services,
et al. The motion of petitioners for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
is denied. Petitioners are allowed until October 23, 1989, within which
to
pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a petition
in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan
and Justice Marshall, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in Brown
v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U. S. 928 (1983), we would deny the petition
for a writ of certiorari without reaching the merits of the motion to pro-
ceed in forma pauperis.
No. 89-127. Philip Randy Castiglione, Petitioner v. United States.
The application for stay addressed to Justice Scalia and referred to the
Court is denied.
No. 89-352. Maurice Silverstein, Petitioner v. New York. The appli-
cation for stay addressed to Justice Marshall and referred to the Court
is denied.

Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted.

MONDAY, OCTOBER 2, 1989
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted. Justice Kennedy took

No. 88-1671. United States Department of Labor, Petitioner .
George R. Triplett, et al.; and
No. 88-1688. Committee on Legal Ethics of the West Virginia State
Bar, Petitioner v. George R. Triplett, et al. Petitions for writs of certio-
rari to the Supreme Court of Appeals of West Virginia granted. The
cases are consolidated and a total of one hour is allotted for oral
argument.
No. 88-1872. Cynthia Rutan, et al., Petitioners v. Republican Party
of Illinois, et al.; and
No. 88-2074. Mark Frech, et al., Petitioners v. Cynthia Rutan, et al.
The motion of Independent Voters of Illinois Independent Precinct
Organization, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae in
No. 88-1872 is granted. Petitions for writs of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit granted. The cases are
consolidated and a total of one hour is allotted for oral argument.
No. 88-1932. United States, Petitioner v. German Munoz Flores.
The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is
granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted. In addressing the justiciability
issues presented in this case, the parties are requested to brief the
applicability of the political question doctrine.
No. 88-1972. Illinois, Petitioner v. Lloyd Perkins. The motion of
respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the Appellate Court of Illinois, Fifth District,
granted.
No. 89-156. Pennsylvania Department of Public Welfare, et al., Peti-
tioners v. Edward J. Davenport, et ux. The motion of respondent for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. Petition for writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit
granted.
No. 88-2035. Adams Fruit Company, Inc., Petitioner v. Ramsford
Barrett, et al. The motion of National Council of Self-Insurers for leave.
to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. Petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit granted.
No. 88-2043. Gerald L. Baliles, Governor of Virginia, et al., Petition-
ers v. Virginia Hospital Association. Petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit granted lim-
ited to Question 1 presented by the petition.

No. 89-38. Guardian Plans, Inc., et al., Petitioners v. Joseph W.
Teague, et al. The motion of American Cemetery Association, et al. for
leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted. Petition for writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit.
denied.

The motion of Association of Bar Defense Counsel for leave to file a
brief as amicus curiae is granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
Supreme Court of California denied.

The motion of Abass Alavi, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae
is granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit denied.

writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District
of Columbia Circuit denied. Justice White took no part in the consider-
ation or decision of this petition.
No. 89-5053. William Glen Boyd, Petitioner v. Alabama. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Alabama denied. Dissenting
statement by Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall. Justice White
would grant certiorari.
No. 89-5119. Daniel Berrigan, et al., Petitioners : Pennsylvania.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania,
Eastern District, denied. Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall would
grant certiorari.

Estate Commission, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, OCTOBER 10. 1989
99
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 88-7535. Michael Terrell, Petitioner v. Terry L. Morris, Super-
intendent, Southern Ohio Correctional Facility. On petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit.
The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the
petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and
the case is remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Dissent-
ing opinion by the Chief Justice with whom Justice White, Justice
O'Connor and Justice Scalia join.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 88-7468. Reginald Whigham, Petitioner v. Dale Foltz, Warden.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Sixth Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States.
Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further consideration in light
of Harris v. Reed, 489 U.S.
(1989).
No. 89-231. Shearson Lehman/American Express, Inc., et al., Peti-
tioners v. Frank L. Bird, Individually and as Trustee of the Frank L.
Bird Profit Sharing Trust, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. The motion of
Securities Industry Association, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici
curiae is granted. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit for further consideration in
light of Rodriguez de Quijas v. Shearson/American Express, Inc., 490
U.S. (1989). Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall and Justice Ste-
vens dissent.
-

100
TUESDAY, OCTOBER 10, 1989
No. 89-265. Easton Publishing Company, Petitioner v. Alfred R.
Boettger. On petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of
Pennsylvania, Eastern District. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, Eastern District, for further consider-
ation in light of The Florida Star v. B. J. F., 491 U.S. (1989).
- –
No. 89-5484. Johnny James, Petitioner v. Texas. On petition for writ
of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas. The motion of
petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for
writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas for further consid-
eration in light of Penry v. Lynaugh, 492 U.S. (1989).

National
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
V.
No.
Railroad Passenger Corp., Applicant
Transporation Communications Union, et al. The motion to direct the
Clerk to file a petition for a writ of certiorari, out-of-time, is denied.
No. A-247. Healthamerica and Pamela Merle, Applicants v. Edward
Menton. The application for stay presented to Justice Kennedy and by
him referred to the Court is granted and it is ordered that the execution
and enforcement of the judgment of the Supreme Court of Alabama,
case No. 87-1110, is stayed pending the timely filing and disposition of
a petition for a writ of certiorari. In the event the petition for a writ of
certiorari is denied, this order terminates automatically. Should the
petition for a writ of certiorari be granted, this order is to remain in
effect pending the issuance of the mandate of this Court. This order is
further conditioned upon the supersedeas bond presently posted with
the Clerk of the Circuit Court of Mobile County, Alabama, Civil Action
No. CV-86-003049, remaining in effect.
No. D-782. In the matter of Everett Emett Ricks, Jr. Everett
Emett Ricks, Jr., of Long Beach, California, having requested to resign
as a member of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name be
stricken from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the Bar
of this Court. The order of disbarment entered August 11, 1989, is va-
cated. The Rule to Show Cause, heretofore issued on May 1, 1989, is
hereby discharged.
No. D-794. In the Matter of Disbarment of Ruben R. Montemayor.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-797. In the Matter of Lawrence Ripes. Lawrence Ripes,
of Northbrook, Illinois, having requested to resign as a member of
3

TUESDAY, OCTOBER 10, 1989
101
the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name be stricken from the
roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the Bar of this Court. The
Rule to Show Cause, heretofore issued on August 11, 1989, is hereby
discharged.
No. D-800. In the Matter of Disbarment of William Francis Xavier
Klan. Disbarment order entered.
No. D-811. In the Matter of Disbarment of Nathan Norton Powell. It
is ordered that Nathan Norton Powell, of Chicago, Illinois, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 8, Original. State of Arizona, Plaintiff v. State of California,
et al. The motion of the state parties to reopen the decree to determine
disputed boundary claims with respect to the Fort Mojave, Colorado
River and Fort Yuma Indian Reservations is granted. Justice Marshall
took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 87–1045. Director, Office of Workers' Compensation Programs,
United States Department of Labor, Petitioner v. Fred Kyle; and
No. 87-1065. National Council on Compensation Insurance, Peti-
tioner v. Fred Kyle and Director, Office of Workers' Compensation Pro-
grams, United States Department of Labor. The motion of respondent
Fred Kyle for attorney's fees is granted and the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit is directed to determine the fee to be
allowed for the work performed by counsel before this Court.
No. 87-1622. Philip Brendale, Petitioner v. Confederated Tribes and
Bands of Yakima Indian Nation, et al.;
No. 87-1697. Stanley Wilkinson, Petitioner v. Confederated Tribes
and Bands of Yakima Indian Nation, et al.; and
No. 87-1711. County of Yakima, et al., Petitioners v. Confederated
Tribes and Bands of Yakima Indian Nation, et al. The motion of
respondents to retax costs is granted and it is ordered that two-thirds
of the cost of the preparation of the joint appendix is assessed against
respondents Confederated Tribes and Bands of Yakima Indian Nation,
et al., and one-third of the cost of the preparation of the joint appendix
is assessed against petitioner Philip Brendale.
No. 87-1965. Marcus C. Zinermon, et al., Petitioners v. Darrell E.
Burch. The motion of American Civil Liberties Union, et al. for leave to
file a brief as amici curiae is granted.

motion.

No. 89-440. Debby Clardy, Executrix of the Estate of Eugene
Clardy, deceased, and Clardy Realty, Inc., Petitioners v. Martha Hoff-
man Sanders. The application for stay presented to Justice Stevens and
by him referred to the Court is granted and it is ordered that the execu-

TUESDAY, OCTOBER 10, 1989
103
tion and enforcement of the judgment of the Supreme Court of Ala-
bama, case No. 87-1070, is stayed pending this Court's action on the
petition for a writ of certiorari. In the event the petition for a writ of
certiorari is denied, this order terminates automatically. Should the
petition for a writ of certiorari be granted, this order is to remain in
effect pending the issuance of the mandate of this Court. This order is
further conditioned upon the supersedeas bond presently posted with
the Clerk of the Circuit Court of Montgomery County, Alabama, Civil
Action No. CV-87-448, remaining in effect.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 87-6700. John Henry Selvage, Petitioner v. James A. Lynaugh,
Director, Texas Department of Corrections. The motion of petitioner
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit
granted limited to Question 1 presented by the petition, but rephrased
as follows: "At the time petitioner was tried, was there 'cause' for not
raising a claim based upon arguments later accepted in Penry v.
Lynaugh, No. 87–6177 (June 26, 1989); and if not, would the application
of a procedural bar to the claim result in a 'fundamental miscarriage of
justice,' Smith v. Murray, 477 U.S. 527, 537–538 (1986)?”
No. 88-7164. Terry Brice Horton, Petitioner v. California. Motion of
petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ
of certiorari to the Court of Appeal of California, Sixth Appellate Dis-
trict, granted.
No. 88-7194. Arthur Lajuane Taylor, Petitioner v. United States.
Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eighth Circuit granted.
No. 89-61. United States, Petitioner v. Filiberto Ojeda Rios, et al.
The motions of respondents for leave to proceed in forma pauperis are
granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit granted.

Corrections, et al., Petitioners v. Jimmie Wayne Jeffers. The motion of
respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit granted.

HABEAS CORPUS DENIED
No. 89-5542. In Re Pearly Wilson, Petitioner. The petition for writ
of habeas corpus is denied.
MANDAMUS DENIED
No. 89-5318. In Re Irving R. Jorgenson, Petitioner;
No. 89-5409. In Re Lum Ogden, Petitioner; and
No. 89-5411. In Re Olayinka Sobamowo, Petitioner. The petitions
for writs of mandamus and/or prohibition are denied.

No. 89-5404. In Re Paul Palmer, Petitioner. The petition for writ of
prohibition is denied.
REHEARINGS DENIED
No. 88-5751. Gregory Van Cleave, Petitioner v. Indiana;
No. 88-5957. Richard E. Grant, Petitioner v. California;
No. 88-5981. Michael Allen Williams, Petitioner v. California;
No. 88-6341. William George Bonin, Petitioner v. California; and
No. 88-6767. Seymour Pollack, Petitioner v. United States. The mo-
tions for leave to file petitions for rehearing are denied.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Monday, October 16, 1989 until
Monday, October 30, 1989.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, OCTOBER 16, 1989
125
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
and Justice Scalia.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 88-928. James M. White, etc., Petitioner v. United States, et al.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit. The writ of certiorari is dismissed as improvidently
granted. Opinion per curiam announced by the Chief Justice. Justice
White dissents.
APPEAL SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 89-301. John Monroe, et al., Appellants v. City of Woodville,
Mississippi, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Southern District of Mississippi. The judgment is vacated and the case
is remanded to the United States District Court for the Southern Dis-
trict of Mississippi with instructions to dismiss the appeal as moot.
United States v. Munsingwear, Inc., 340 U.S. 36 (1950).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-246. Consumer Value Stores, Applicant v. Board of Pharmacy
of New Jersey. The application for stay addressed to Justice Blackmun
and referred to the Court is denied.
No. D-793. In the Matter of Disbarment of Prince Cartwright, Jr.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-796. In the Matter of Disbarment of Glenn Dale Cannon. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-804. In the Matter of Disbarment of George W. McManus, Jr.
George W. McManus, Jr., of Baltimore, Maryland, having requested to
resign as a member of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name
be stricken from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the
Bar of this Court. The Rule to Show Cause, heretofore issued on Au-
gust 11, 1989, is hereby discharged.

126
MONDAY, OCTOBER 16, 1989
No. D-812. In the Matter of Disbarment of George Towfick Mahshie.
It is ordered that George Towfick Mahshie, of DeWitt, New York, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-813. In the Matter of Disbarment of Arthur Berlin Kramer. It
is ordered that Arthur Berlin Kramer, of Charlotte, North Carolina, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 111, Original. State of Delaware, Plaintiff v. State of New York.
The motion of North Carolina for leave to intervene is referred to the
Special Master. The Report of the Special Master on motions to inter-
vene is received and ordered filed.
No. 87-1720. Hubert C. Taylor, Petitioner v. Peabody Coal Com-
pany, et al. The motion of counsel for approval of attorney fees of peti-
tioner, Herbert Taylor, is referred to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Seventh Circuit to determine whether fees are to be
allowed at all and then, if so, to determine their amount for the work
performed by counsel before this Court.
No. 88–192. McKesson Corporation, Petitioner v. Division of Alco-
holic Beverages and Tobacco, Department of Business Regulation of
Florida, et al. The motion of California, et al. for leave to file a brief as
amici curiae is granted.
No. 88-1668. Atlantic Richfield Company, Petitioner v. USA Petro-
leum Company. The motion of Service Station Dealers of America for
leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted.
No. 89-353. Jennie Sanchez, et al., Petitioners v. William Bond, et al.
The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this case expressing the
views of the United States.

writ of certiorari to the Superior Court of Pennsylvania, Harrisburg Of-
fice, granted.

al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, OCTOBER 30, 1989
141
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 88-1601. Pullman-Standard, Inc., Petitioner v. Louis Swint, et
al.; and
No. 88-1602. Louis Swint, et al., Petitioners v. Pullman-Standard,
et al. On petitions for writs of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. The petitions for writs of certiorari
are granted. The judgment is vacated and the cases are remanded to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit for further
consideration in light of Patterson v. McLean Credit Union, 491 U.S.
(1989), Wards Cove Packing Company, Inc. v. Atonio, 490 U.S.
(1989), and Owens v. Okure, 488 U.S. -
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
(1989).
No. Robert E. Miller, et al., Petitioners v. Farmers Alliance
Mutual Insurance Company. The motion to direct the Clerk to file a
petition for a writ of certiorari, out-of-time, is denied.
No. A-269. Donald Rice, Applicant v. United States. The application
for release on bond addressed to Justice Brennan and referred to the
Court is denied.
No. A-276. Salvatore J. Pisello, Applicant v. United States. The
application for stay addressed to Justice Brennan and referred to the
Court is denied.
No. D-798. In the Matter of Disbarment of Michael Edwin Zealy.
Disbarment order entered.
No. 65, Original. State of Texas, Plaintiff v. State of New Mexico.
The motion of the Special Master for allowance of interim fees and dis-
bursements is granted and the Special Master is awarded $55,936.76 to
be paid equally by the parties.
No. 109, Original. States of Oklahoma and Texas, Plaintiffs v. State
of New Mexico. The interim report of the Special Master is received

142
MONDAY, OCTOBER 30, 1989
and ordered filed. The motion of the Special Master for allowance of
compensation and reimbursement of expenses is granted and the Spe-
cial Master is awarded $22,200.83 - one-third to be paid by each party.
No. 111, Original. State of Delaware, Plaintiff v. State of New York.
The motion of Texas for leave to file an amended complaint in interven-
tion is referred to the Special Master.
No. 88-1125. Jane Hodgson, et al, Petitioners v. Minnesota, et al.
The motion of Jeff White, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is
denied. The motion of Stanley John for leave to file a brief as amicus
curiae is denied. The motion of Kenneth Fisher for leave to file a brief
as amicus curiae is denied. The motion of Herbert Ratner for leave to
file a brief as amicus curiae is denied.
No. 88-1400. Franchise Tax Board of California, et al., Petitioners v.
Alcan Aluminium Limited, et al. The motion of respondents for re-
consideration of order denying motion for divided argument is denied.
The request of respondents to submit the case on the briefs is denied.
,
No. 88-1503. Nancy Beth Cruzan, by her parents and co-guardians,
Lester L. Cruzan, et ux., Petitioners v. Director, Missouri Department
of Health, et al. The motion of Frances Ambrose for leave to file a brief
as amicus curiae is denied. The motion of Ralph Buglioni for leave to
file a brief as amicus curiae is denied. The motion of Jack Butler for
leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is denied. The motion of Center for
Catholic Policy of the Free Congress Foundation for leave to file a brief
as amicus curiae is denied. The motion of Christian Action Council, et
al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is denied. The motion of Philip
Dreisbach for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is denied. The mo-
tion of James Dunlap for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is denied.
The motion of Lawrence J. Frieders for leave to file a brief as amicus
curiae is denied. The motion of Mechtild Grothues for leave to file a
brief as amicus curiae is denied. The motion of Paul Marx for leave to
file a brief as amicus curiae is denied. The motion of J.G. Morriss for
leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is denied. The motion of National
Nurses for Life for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is denied. The
motion of Nurses for Life of Missouri for leave to file a brief as amicus
curiae is denied. The motion of Pharmacists for Life for leave to file a
brief as amicus curiae is denied. The motion of Right to Life League of
Southern California, Inc. for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is
denied. The motion of Herbert Ratner for leave to file a brief as amicus
curiae is denied.

MONDAY, OCTOBER 30, 1989
143
No. 88-1725. Juan Francisco Venegas, Petitioner v. Michael R.
Mitchell. The motion of petitioner to dispense with printing the joint
appendix is granted.
No. 88-1932. United States, Petitioner v. German Munoz-Flores.
The motion of the Solicitor General to dispense with printing the joint
appendix is granted.
No. 88-1951. United States, Petitioner v. Frances L. Dalm. The mo-
tion of the Solicitor General to dispense with printing the joint appendix
is granted.
No. 88-1972. Illinois, Petitioner v. Lloyd Perkins. The motion for ap-
pointment of counsel is granted and it is ordered that Daniel M. Kirwin,
Esquire, of Mt. Vernon, Illinois, is appointed to serve as counsel for the
respondent in this case.
No. 88-6546. Albert Duro, Petitioner v. Edward Reina, Chief of Po-
lice, Salt River Department of Public Safety, Salt River Pima-Maricopa
Indian Community, et al. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave
to participate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided argu-
ment is granted.
No. 88-7146. Jonas H. Whitmore, individually and as next friend of
Ronald Gene Simmons, Petitioner v. Arkansas, et al. The motion of
Washington Legal Foundation, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici
curiae is granted.
No. 89-65. Fort Stewart Schools, Petitioner v. Federal Labor Rela-
tions Authority, et al. The motion of the Acting Solicitor General to
dispense with printing the joint appendix is granted.
No. 89-400. David Lucas, et al., Appellants v. Judy Townsend, etc.,
et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this case express-
ing the views of the United States.
No. 89-5398. Joseph W. Johnston, Petitioner v. Acting Commis-
sioner of Social Security. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until November 20,
1989, within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and
to submit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this
Court. Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall, dissenting: For the rea-
sons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928 (1983), we
would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari without reaching the
merits of the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.
No. 89-5700. Andrew Reis, Petitioner v. New York State Housing
Finance Agency. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until November 20, 1989,

144
MONDAY, OCTOBER 30, 1989
within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to sub-
mit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court.
Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun and Justice Ste-
vens, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co.,
Inc., 464 U.S. 928 (1983), we would deny the petition for a writ of cer-
tiorari without reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in forma
pauperis.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 6, 1989
171
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 89-401. Cyril H. Wecht, President of the Allegheny County
Board of Prison Inspectors, et al., Petitioners v. Inmates of the Alle-
gheny County Jail, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. The petition for writ of
certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit for further
consideration in light of University of Texas v. Camenisch, 451 U.S.
390 (1981).
-
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. Ratinavelu Ramachandran, Petitioner v. Secretary of the
Navy. The motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ of cer-
tiorari, out-of-time, is denied.
No. Larry David Stocks, Petitioner v. United States. The mo-
tion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ of certiorari, out-of-
time, is denied. Justice Blackmun dissents and would grant the motion.
No. D-814. In the Matter of Disbarment of Zale A. Bernstein. It is
ordered that Zale A. Bernstein, of Fort Lauderdale, Florida, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-815. In the Matter of Disbarment of Paul Shimek, Jr. It is or-
dered that Paul Shimek, Jr., of Pensacola, Florida, be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-816. In the Matter of Disbarment of Robert Thomas Chan-
dler. It is ordered that Robert Thomas Chandler, of Spokane, Washing-
ton, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule

172
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 6, 1989
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

dered that Phillip Singer, of Beverly Hills, California, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

ment of Real Estate, et al. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 6, 1989
175
in forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until November 27,
1989, within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and
to submit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this
Court. Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun and Justice
Stevens, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald
Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928 (1983), we would deny the petition for a writ of
certiorari without reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in
forma pauperis.
No. 89-5728. Otto A. Preuss, Petitioner v. District of Columbia, et
al. The application for stay addressed to Justice Brennan and referred
to the Court is denied.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
OPINIONS
No. 88-42. Olaf A. Hallstrom, et ux., Petitioners v. Tillamook
County. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice O'Connor.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall with whom Justice Brennan
joins.
No. 88-995. Northbrook National Insurance Company, Petitioner v.
Larry W. Brewer, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States.
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Marshall. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Stevens.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Marshall
Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, and
Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 88-1640. Michigan Citizens for an Independent Press, et al., Pe-
titioners v. Dick Thornburgh, Attorney General of the United States,
et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
District of Columbia Circuit. The judgment of the United States Court
of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit is affirmed by an equally
divided Court. Opinion per curiam announced by the Chief Justice.
Justice White took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.

ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. Nina Firey, Petitioner v. Washington, et al. The motion to
direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ of certiorari, out-of-time, is
denied.
No. D-799. In the Matter of Disbarment of Arvin Lee Davis. Disbar-
ment order entered.
No. D-802. In the Matter of Disbarment of Warren E. Rollman. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-803. In the Matter of Disbarment of Dennis R. DiRicco. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-828. In the Matter of Disbarment of Michael Joseph Kavan-
augh. It is ordered that Michael Joseph Kavanaugh, of Millford, Michi-
gan, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-829. In the Matter of Disbarment of Herman T. Isis. It is or-
dered that Herman T. Isis, of Coral Gables, Florida, be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-830. In the Matter of Disbarment of Brandt Nicholson. It is
ordered that Brandt Nicholson, of San Francisco, California, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-831. In the Matter of Disbarment of E. Lawrence Brass. It is
ordered that E. Lawrence Brass, of Hempstead, New York, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-832. In the Matter of Disbarment of Lewis M. Batkin. It is
ordered that Lewis M. Batkin, of Hempstead, New York, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable

200
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 13, 1989
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-833. In the Matter of Disbarment of Joseph R. Laird, Jr. It is
ordered that Joseph R. Laird, Jr., of Sherman Oaks, California, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-834. In the Matter of Disbarment of John D. Raikos. It is or-
dered that John D. Raikos, of Indianapolis, Indiana, be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-835. In the Matter of Disbarment of Charles Monroe Thorp,
III. It is ordered that Charles Monroe Thorp, III, of Pittsburgh, Penn-
sylvania, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a
rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause
why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 74, Original. State of Georgia, Plaintiff v. State of South Caro-
lina. The motion of South Carolina for leave to file a rebuttal brief is
granted.
No. 88-1125. Jane Hodgson, et al, Petitioners v. Minnesota, et al.;
and
No. 88-1309. Minnesota, et al., Petitioners v. Jane Hodgson, et al.
The motion of Abortion Rights Council, et al. for leave to consider their
brief as amici curiae filed in No. 88-790, Turnock v. Ragsdale, and
No. 88-805, Ohio v. Akron Center for Reproductive Health, filed in
these cases is granted.
No. 88-1597. Board of Education of the Westside Community Schools,
etc., et al., Petitioners v. Bridget C. Mergens, by and through her next
friend, Daniel N. Mergens, et al. The motion of the Solicitor General for
divided argument is granted.
No. 88-1650. Francine Tafflin, et al., Petitioners v. Jeffrey A. Levitt,
et al. The motion of petitioners for leave to file petition for rehearing
of partial denial of petition for writ of certiorari is denied.
No. 88-1671. United States Department of Labor, Petitioner v.
George R. Triplett, et al.; and
No. 88-1688. Committee on Legal Ethics of the West Virginia State
Bar, Petitioner v. George R. Triplett, et al. The motion of the Solicitor
General to dispense with printing the joint appendix is granted.

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 13, 1989
201
No. 88-1872. Cynthia Rutan, et al., Petitioners v. Republican Party
of Illinois, et al.; and
No. 88-2074. Mark Frech, et al., Petitioners v. Cynthia Rutan, et al.
The motion of petitioners/cross-respondents to dispense with printing
the joint appendix is granted.
No. 89-459. Delta Air Lines, Inc., Petitioner v. Association of Flight
Attendants, AFL-CIO. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in
this case expressing the views of the United States.
No. 89-510. Larry R. Meachum, Commissioner, Connecticut Depart-
ment of Corrections, Petitioner v. Wayne B. Alexander. The motion of
respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted.
No. 89-555. Benton Musslewhite, Petitioner v. State Bar of Texas.
The application for stay and other relief addressed to Justice Marshall
and referred to the Court is denied.
No. 89-682. Colorado Department of Social Services, et al., Petition-
ers v. AMISUB (PSL), dba AMI St. Luke's Hospital, Inc., et al. The
motion of respondents to expedite consideration of the petition for a
writ of certiorari is denied.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 89-255. United States, Petitioner v. Energy Resources Co.,
Inc., et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the First Circuit granted.
No. 89-5383. Mark Howlett, a minor, by and through Elizabeth.
Howlett, his mother, natural guardian and next friend, Petitioner v.
Scott Rose, as Superintendent of Schools for Pinellas County, Florida,

the petition for writ of certiorari to the District Court of Appeal of Flor-
ida, Second District, granted.

THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 16, 1989
213
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 89-5989. Arthur James Julius, Petitioner v. Charlie Jones, War-
den. The application for stay of execution of sentence of death pre-
sented to Justice Kennedy and by him referred to the Court is denied.
The petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals.
for the Eleventh Circuit is denied. Dissenting statement by Justice

(JOURNAL)
FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 17, 1989
215
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 8, Original. State of Arizona, Plaintiff v. State of California, et
al. It is ordered that Robert B. McKay, Esquire, of New York, New
York, Professor Emeritus, New York University School of Law, be
appointed Special Master in this case to reopen decree to determine dis-
puted boundary claims with respect to the Fort Mojave, Colorado River
and Fort Yuma Indian Reservations. He shall have the authority to fix
the time and conditions for the filing of additional pleadings and to
direct subsequent proceedings, and the authority to summon witnesses,
issue subpoenas, and take such evidence as may be introduced and such
as he may deem it necessary to call for. The Special Master is directed
to submit such reports as he may deem appropriate.
The compensation of the Special Master, the allowances to him, the
compensation paid to his legal, technical, stenographic, and clerical as-
sistants, the cost of printing his report, and all other proper expenses,
including travel expenses, shall be charged against and be borne by the
parties in such proportion as the Court may hereafter direct. Justice
Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision of this order.



(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 20, 1989
217
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-377. Mark Henry Lankford, Applicant v. Idaho. The applica-
tion for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice
O'Connor and by her referred to the Court is granted pending the
timely filing and disposition by this Court of a petition for a writ of cer-
tiorari. Should the petition for a writ of certiorari be denied, this stay
terminates automatically. In the event the petition for a writ of certio-
rari is granted, this stay shall continue in effect pending the issuance of
the mandate of this Court.



(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 22, 1989
219
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 89-5892. Benjamin Wai Silva, Petitioner v. California. The appli-
cation for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice
O'Connor and by her referred to the Court is granted pending the dis-
position by this Court of the petition for writ of certiorari. Should the
petition for a writ of certiorari be denied, this stay terminates automat-
ically. In the event the petition for a writ of certiorari is granted, this
stay shall continue pending the issuance of the mandate of this Court.



(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 27. 1989
221
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEAL SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 89-5863. Winifred Goudie, aka Marie Webster, Appellant .
General Telephone Company of the Southeast, et al. Appeal from the
Circuit Court of West Virginia Jefferson County. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal
was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. D-787. In the Matter of Disbarment of Frank G. Prantil. Disbar-
ment order entered.
No. D-836. In the Matter of Disbarment of James Clifford Evans. It
is ordered that James Clifford Evans, of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-837. In the Matter of Disbarment of Frank J. Marcone. It is
ordered that Frank J. Marcone, of Springfield, Pennsylvania, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-838. In the Matter of Disbarment of Barry Leonard Adelman.
It is ordered that Barry Leonard Adelman, of Philadelphia, Pennsylva-
nia, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-839. In the Matter of Disbarment of William S. Higgin-
botham. It is ordered that William S. Higginbotham, of Athens, Geor-
gia, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

222
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 27, 1989
No. D-840. In the Matter of Disbarment of Charles A. Pemberton. It
is ordered that Charles A. Pemberton, of Decatur, Georgia, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-841. In the Matter of Disbarment of Milliard Eugene Farley.
It is ordered that Milliard Eugene Farley, of Cleveland, Ohio, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 108, Original. State of Nebraska, Plaintiff v. States of Wyoming
and Colorado. The third motion of the Special Master for compensation
and reimbursement of expenses is granted and the Special Master is
awarded $97,843.24 to be paid to him 20 percent by the United States
and 40 percent each by the states of Nebraska and Wyoming.
No. 87-6700. John Henry Selvage, Petitioner v. James A. Lynaugh,
Director, Texas Department of Corrections. The motion of petitioner to
suspend briefing and further consideration is denied. The motion of
petitioner to certify question to Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas is
denied.
No. 88-325. American Trucking Associations, Inc., et al., Petitioners
v. Maurice Smith, Director, Arkansas Highway and Transportation De-
partment, et al. The motion of petitioners for leave to file a supplemen-
tal brief on reargument is granted.
No. 88-1503. Nancy Beth Cruzan, by her parents and co-guardians,
Lester L. Cruzan, et ux., Petitioners v. Director, Missouri Department
of Health, et al. The motion of respondent Thad C. McCanse, Guardian
ad Litem, for divided argument is denied.
No. 88-1595. Kaiser Aluminum & Chemical Corporation, et al., Peti-
tioners . Joseph A. Bonjorno, et al.; and
No. 88-1771. Joseph A. Bonjorno, et al., Petitioners v. Kaiser Alumi-
num & Chemical Corporation, et al. The motion of respondents/cross-
petitioners, Joseph Bonjorno, et al., to open oral argument and to
present a summary outline of issues for use in determining the order of
oral argument is denied.
No. 88-1897. Michigan Department of State Police, et al., Petitioners
v. Rick Sitz, et al. The motion of Insurance Institute for Highway

MANDAMUS DENIED
No. 89-560. In Re Jack G. Norton, Petitioner. The petition for a writ
of mandamus and/or prohibition is denied.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

OPINIONS
No. 87-1979. Chesapeake and Ohio Railway Company, Petitioner v.
Nancy J. Schwalb and William McGlone; and
No. 88-127. Norfolk & Western Railway Company, Petitioner v.
Robert T. Goode, Jr. On writs of certiorari to the Supreme Court of
Virginia. Judgments reversed and cases remanded to the Supreme
Court for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice White. Concurring opinion by Justice Black-
mun with whom Justice Marshall and Justice O'Connor join. Opinion by
Justice Stevens concurring in the judgment.
No. 88-952. United States, Appellant v. Sperry Corporation, et al.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Cir-
cuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opin-
ion by Justice White.

ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 89-6144. Dalton Prejean, Petitioner v. Larry D. Smith, Warden,
et al. The application for stay of execution of sentence of death pre-
sented to Justice White and by him referred to the Court is granted
pending the disposition by this Court of the petition for writ of certio-
rari. Should the petition for a writ of certiorari be denied, this stay ter-
minates automatically. In the event the petition for a writ of certiorari
is granted, this stay shall continue pending the issuance of the mandate
of this Court.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.'
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-390. Suzanne Clark, Applicant v. George Clark, III, et al. The
application for stay addressed to the Chief Justice and referred to the
Court is denied.

Pitts, et al. The application for stay of mandate of the United States.
Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit presented to Justice Ken-
nedy and by him referred to the Court is denied. The order heretofore
entered by Justice Kennedy on November 22, 1989 is vacated.
No. D-777. In the Matter of Disbarment of Michael Cooper. Disbar-
ment order entered.
No. D-795. In the Matter of Disbarment of John J. Held. Disbarment
order entered.
No. D-805. In the Matter of Disbarment of Elliott H. Pollack. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-842. In the Matter of Disbarment of Donald S. Eisenberg. It
is ordered that Donald S. Eisenberg, of Miami Beach, Florida, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-843. In the Matter of Disbarment of Lawrence Brown. It is
ordered that Lawrence Brown, of Encino, California, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-844. In the Matter of Disbarment of R. Lewis Ray. It is or-
dered that R. Lewis Ray, of Winston-Salem, North Carolina, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

MONDAY, DECEMBER 4, 1989
No. D-845. In the Matter of Disbarment of C. Michael Davis. It is
ordered that C. Michael Davis, of Houston, Texas, be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-846. In the Matter of Disbarment of Peter Sanchez-Navarro,
Jr. It is ordered that Peter Sanchez-Navarro, Jr., of Houston, Texas,
be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 105, Original. State of Kansas, Plaintiff v. State of Colorado.
The motion of the Special Master for award of interim fees and ex-
penses is granted and the Special Master is awarded a total of
$83,082.76 to be paid by Kansas, Colorado and the United States pursu-
ant to the allocation order filed by the Special Master on October 9,
1989.
No. 111, Original. State of Delaware, Plaintiff v. State of New York.
The motion of Minnesota for leave to intervene is referred to the Spe-
cial Master. The motion of California, Michigan, Nebraska, Ohio and
Rhode Island for leave to file a complaint in intervention is referred to
the Special Master. The motion of Colorado for leave to intervene is re-
ferred to the Special Master. The motion of Arkansas, Florida, Iowa,
Mississippi, Missouri, New Hampshire and West Virginia for leave to
file a complaint in intervention is referred to the Special Master.
No. 88-1872. Cynthia Rutan, et al., Petitioners v. Republican Party
of Illinois, et al. The motion of Independent Voters of Illinois-Independ-
ent Precinct Organization, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae
is granted.
No. 88-1897. Michigan Department of State Police, et al., Petitioners
v. Rick Sitz, et al. The motion of National Organization of Mothers
Against Drunk Driving for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is
granted. The motion of Washington Legal Foundation, et al. for leave
to file a brief as amici curiae is granted. The motion of American Alli-
ance for Rights and Responsibilities, Inc., et al. for leave to file a brief
as amici curiae is granted. The motion of National Governors' Associa-
tion, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted. The mo-
tion of Appellate Committee of the California District Attorneys Asso-
ciation for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted.

Х

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, DECEMBER 5. 1989
267
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today the Court has adopted revised rules governing practice and
procedure before the Court. The revised rules will become effective on
January 1, 1990, and will supersede the rules of the Court currently in
effect."
ORDER
It is ordered that the revised Rules of this Court, today approved by
the Court and lodged with the Clerk, shall become effective January 1,
1990, and be printed as an appendix to the United States Reports.
It is further ordered that the Rules promulgated April 14, 1980, and
appearing in Volume 445 of the United States Reports, together with
all amendments thereof be, and they hereby are, rescinded as of De-
cember 31, 1989, and that the revised Rules shall govern all proceed-
ings in cases thereafter commenced and, in so far as practicable, all pro-
ceedings in cases then pending.
OPINIONS
No. 88-791. Pavelic & Leflore, Petitioner v. Marvel Entertainment
Group, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Second Circuit. Judgment reversed in part and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Scalia. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Marshall.
No. 88-840. Golden State Transit Corp., Petitioner v. City of Los
Angeles. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by Justice Ken-
nedy with whom the Chief Justice and Justice O'Connor join.
No. 88-124. Lynn L. Breininger, Petitioner v. Sheet Metal Workers.
International Association Local Union No. 6. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment Af-
firmed in part, reversed in part and case remanded to the Court of Ap-

268
TUESDAY, DECEMBER 5, 1989
peals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Brennan. Opinion by Justice Stevens concur-
ring in part and dissenting in part with whom Justice Scalia joins.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,

ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. . Samuel M. Humphrey, Petitioner v. Ralph Bates, et al. The
motion to direct the Clerk to file the petition for a writ of certiorari,
out-of-time, is denied. Justice Blackmun dissents and would grant the
motion.
No. D-806. In the Matter of Disbarment of Richard Mario Biaggi.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-809. In the Matter of Disbarment of Bernard Gordon Ehrlich.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-810. In the Matter of Disbarment of Stanley Simon. Disbar-
ment order entered.
No. D-817. In the Matter of Phillip Singer. Phillip Singer, of Beverly
Hills, California, having requested to resign as a member of the Bar of
this Court, it is ordered that his name be stricken from the roll of
attorneys admitted to practice before the Bar of this Court. The Rule
to Show Cause, heretofore issued on November 6, 1989, is hereby
discharged.
No. D-847. In the Matter of Disbarment of Walter L. Nixon, Jr. It is
ordered that Walter L. Nixon, Jr., of Biloxi, Mississippi, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-848. In the Matter of Disbarment of Gerald Duane Williams.
It is ordered that Gerald Duane Williams, of Portland, Oregon, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 88-1281. Alex Ngiraingas, et al., Petitioners v. Francisco Q.
Sanchez, etc., et al. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to par-

272
MONDAY, DECEMBER 11, 1989
ticipate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument is
granted. Justice Kennedy took no part in the consideration or decision
of this motion.

Alcan Aluminium Limited, et al. The motion of respondent Imperial
Chemical Industries PLC to expunge representations of counsel made
during oral argument is denied.

v. Rick.Sitz, et al. The motion of Mothers Against Drunk Driving Michi-

vided argument and for additional time for oral argument is denied. The

respondent to supplement the record is granted.

The motion of Neuromedical Technologies, Inc. for leave to file a brief
as amicus curiae is granted. Justice O'Connor took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this motion.

Inc., et al. The motion of the Solicitor General to dispense with printing
the joint appendix is granted.
No. 89-579. Charter Company, Petitioner v. Certified Class in the
Charter Securities Litigation, et al. The motion of the parties to defer
consideration of the petition for a writ of certiorari is granted.
No. 89-5884. Franklin Miller, Petitioner v. Howard Hall. The motion
of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied. Peti-
tioner is allowed until January 2, 1990, within which to pay the
docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a petition in compli-
ance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan, Justice.
Marshall and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in
Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928 (1983), we would deny the pe-
tition for a writ of certiorari without reaching the merits of the motion
to proceed in forma pauperis.

No. 89-650. Richard Dugger, Secretary, Florida Department of Cor-
rections, et al., Petitioners v. Theodore Christopher Harris. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eleventh Circuit denied. Justice Brennan, concurring in the denial of
certiorari: I agree that respondent's lawyers rendered ineffective as-
sistance of counsel in violation of the Sixth and Fourteenth Amend-
ments. Adhering to my view that the death penalty is in all circum-

278
MONDAY, DECEMBER 11, 1989
stances cruel and unusual punishment prohibited by the Eighth and
Fourteenth Amendments, see Gregg v. Georgia, 428 U.S. 153, 227
(1976) (Brennan, J., dissenting), I would hold that the State is pre-
cluded on remand from imposing a sentence of death.

OPINIONS
No. 88-1203. Hoffmann-La Roche Inc., Petitioner v. Richard Sper-
ling, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Third Circuit. Judgment affirmed and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Justice Kennedy. Dissenting opinion by Jus-
tice Scalia with whom the Chief Justice joins.
No. 88-1083. John Doe Agency and John Doe Government Agency,
Petitioners v. John Doe Corporation. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Blackmun.
Statement by Justice Blackmun. Concurring opinion by Justice Bren-

MONDAY, DECEMBER 11, 1989
279D
nan. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by Jus-
tice Scalia with whom Justice Marshall joins.
No. 88-1474. United States, Petitioner . Goodyear Tire and Rubber
Company and Affiliates. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Marshall.
