No. D-878. In the Matter of Disbarment of Jeffrey Mark Schwartz.
It is ordered that Jeffrey Mark Schwartz, of New York, New York, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-879. In the Matter of Disbarment of Ronald Etheridge Ander-
son. It is ordered that Ronald Etheridge Anderson, of Huntington.
Park, California, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court
and that a rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to
show cause why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in
this Court.
No. D-880. In the Matter of Disbarment of Hesper A. Jackson, Jr. It
is ordered that Hesper A. Jackson, Jr., of Brooklyn, New York, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-881. In the Matter of Disbarment of Daniel W. Shoemaker. It
is ordered that Daniel W. Shoemaker, of Taneytown, Maryland, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

ordered that Thomas W. Tierney, of Kansas City, Missouri, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable

the joint appendix is granted.
No. 89-5011. Larry Joe Powers, Petitioner v. Ohio. The motion for
appointment of counsel is granted and it is ordered that Robert L.

506
MONDAY, MARCH 26, 1990
Lane, Esquire, of Columbus, Ohio, is appointed to serve as counsel for
the petitioner in this case.
No. 89-6622. Verlan J. Kliewer, Petitioner v. New Jersey. The mo-
tion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied. Peti-
tioner is allowed until April 16, 1990, within which to pay the docketing
fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in compliance with
Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan and Justice Mar-
shall, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co.,
Inc., 464 U. S. 928 (1983), we would deny the petition for a writ of cer-
tiorari without reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in forma
pauperis.
No. 89-7005. David R. Harris, Petitioner v. Texas. The application
for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice White
and by him referred to the Court is granted pending disposition by this
Court of the petition for writ of certiorari. Should the petition for a writ
of certiorari be denied, this stay terminates automatically. In the event
the petition for a writ of certiorari is granted, this stay shall continue
pending the issuance of the mandate of this Court.
CERTIORARI GRANTED

Independent School District No. 89, Oklahoma County, Oklahoma, Pe-
titioner v. Robert L. Dowell, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the

TUESDAY, MARCH 27, 1990
519
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
OPINIONS
No. 88-1671. United States Department of Labor, Petitioner v.
George R. Triplett, et al.; and
No. 88-1688. Committee on Legal Ethics of the West Virginia State
Bar, Petitioner v. George R. Triplett, et al. On writs of certiorari to the
Supreme Court of Appeals of West Virginia. Judgment reversed and
cases remanded to the Supreme Court of Appeals for further proceed-
ings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Scalia. Concurring opinion by Justice Stevens. Opinion by Justice Mar-
shall concurring in the judgment and with whom Justice Brennan joins
as to Part II. Separate statement by Justice Brennan.
No. 88-1569. Richard H. Austin, Michigan Secretary of State and
Frank J. Kelley, Michigan Attorney General, Appellants v. Michigan
Chamber of Commerce. Appeal from the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to
the Court of Appeals for further proceeding in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Marshall. Concurring opinion
by Justice Brennan. Concurring opinion by Justice Stevens. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Scalia. Dissenting opinion by Justice Kennedy with
whom Justice O'Connor and Justice Scalia join.

Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
OPINION
No. 88-6873. Chandler Clemons, Petitioner v. Mississippi. On writ
of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Mississippi. Judgment vacated
and case remanded to the Supreme Court for further proceedings not
inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice White.
Opinion by Justice Brennan concurring in part and dissenting in part.
Opinion by Justice Blackmun concurring in part and dissenting in part
with whom Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall, and Justice Stevens join.

(JOURNAL)
FRIDAY, MARCH 30, 1990
523
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 89-1433. United States, Appellant v. Shawn D. Eichman, David
Gerald Blalock and Scott W. Tyler. Appeal from the United States Dis-
trict Court for the District of Columbia; and
No. 89–1434. United States, Appellant v. Mark John Haggerty, Car-
los Garza, Jennifer Proctor Campbell and Darius Allen Strong. Appeal
from the United States District Court for the Western District of
Washington. The motion of the Speaker and Leadership Group of the
House of Representatives for leave to file, as amici curiae, a printed
brief that differs from the previously submitted typewritten brief is
granted. The motion of the Solicitor General to expedite consideration
of the statements as to jurisdiction is granted. In these cases probable
jurisdiction is noted. The cases are consolidated and a total of one hour
is allotted for oral argument. The brief of the Solicitor General is to be
filed with the Clerk of the Court and served upon appellees on or before
3:00 p.m., Wednesday, April 18, 1990. The brief(s) of the appellees is to
be filed with the Clerk of the Court and served upon the Solicitor Gen-
eral on or before 3:00 p.m., Thursday, May 3, 1990. Any reply brief is to
be filed with the Clerk of the Court and served upon the appellees on or
before 3:00 p.m., Thursday, May 10, 1990. The cases are set for oral
argument at 10:00 a.m., Monday, May 14, 1990.

ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. John F. Keane, Petitioner . New York, etc. The motion to
direct the Clerk to docket an appeal that does not comply with the
Rules of the Court is denied.
No. D-851. In the Matter of Disbarment of Edwin Lawrence Dwor-
kin. Disbarment order entered.
No. D-886. In the Matter of Disbarment of Frank Moses McCann. It
is ordered that Frank Moses McCann, of Lynchburg, Virginia, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-887. In the Matter of Disbarment of Leopoldo Thomas Ara-
gon. It is ordered that Leopoldo Thomas Aragon, of Jackson, Missis-
sippi, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a
rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause
why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-888. In the Matter of Disbarment of Ronald J. Raben. It is
ordered that Ronald J. Raben, of St. Louis, Missouri, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-889. In the Matter of Disbarment of Jack Martin Mazur. It is
ordered that Jack Martin Mazur, of St. Louis, Missouri, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

liams Natural Gas Company, et al. The Solicitor General is invited to
file a brief in this case expressing the views of the United States.

ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-683. Daniel Vasquez, Warden. Applicant c. Robert A. Harris.
The application of the Attorney General of California to vacate the
order of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit,
dated March 30, 1990, staying the execution of sentence of death, pre-
sented to Justice O'Connor and by her referred to the Court, is denied.
The Chief Justice, Justice Scalia and Justice Kennedy would grant the
application to vacate the stay.



(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, APRIL 16, 1990
541
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 88-7000. James R. Stringer, Petitioner . Lee Roy Black, Com-
missioner, Mississippi Department of Corrections. On petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the
petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and
the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit for further consideration in light of Clemons v. Missis-
sippi, 494 U.S. — (1990).
No. 88-7358. Bobby Joe Pinkney, Petitioner . Mississippi. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Mississippi. The mo-
tion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the peti-
tion for writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and the
case is remanded to the Supreme Court of Mississippi for further con-
sideration in light of Clemons v. Mississippi, 494 U.S. — (1990).
No. 89-1040. Robert S. Chappell, Petitioner v. United States. On pe-
tition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Seventh Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Seventh Circuit for further consideration in light of the
position asserted by the Solicitor General in his brief for the United
States filed February 27, 1990.
No. 89-6893. Donald Eugene Petary, Petitioner . Missouri. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Missouri. The motion
of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for
writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the Supreme Court of Missouri for further consideration in
light of McKoy v. North Carolina, 494 U.S. (1990) and Boyde v.
California, 494 U.S. . (1990).

542
-
MONDAY, APRIL 16, 1990
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. James L. Clark, Petitioner v. Community Service Publish-
ing Inc., et al. The motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ
of certiorari, out-of-time, is denied.
No. D-842. In the Matter of Disbarment of Donald S. Eisenberg.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-845. In the Matter of Disbarment of C. Michael Davis. Disbar-
ment order entered.
No. D-862. In the Matter of Melvin A. Heller. Melvin A. Heller, of
Chicago, Illinois, having requested to resign as a member of the Bar of
this Court, it is ordered that his name be stricken from the roll of attor-
neys admitted to practice before the Bar of this Court. The Rule to
Show Cause, heretofore issued on February 20, 1990, is hereby
discharged.
No. D-863. In the Matter of Jerrold L. Morris. Jerrold L. Morris, of
Chicago, Illinois, having requested to resign as a member of the Bar of
this Court, it is ordered that his name be stricken from the roll of attor-
neys admitted to practice before the Bar of this Court. The Rule to
Show Cause, heretofore issued on February 26, 1990, is hereby
discharged.
No. D-865. In the Matter of Earl Rumsey Boyce. Earl Rumsey
Boyce, of Palm Beach, Florida, having requested to resign as a member
of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name be stricken from the
roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the Bar of this Court. The
Rule to Show Cause, heretofore issued on February 26, 1990, is hereby
discharged.
No. D-866. In the Matter of Disbarment of Frank Diaz Silveira. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-890. In the Matter of Disbarment of Mac W. Hancock, III. It
is ordered that Mac W. Hancock, III, of Houston, Texas, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-891. In the Matter of Disbarment of George A. Day. It is or-
dered that George A. Day, of Brownwood, Texas, be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-892. In the Matter of Disbarment of John A. Shorter, Jr. It is
ordered that John A. Shorter, Jr., of Washington, D.C., be suspended
"

MONDAY, APRIL 16, 1990
543
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 88-2041. Everett A. Sisson, Petitioner v. Burton B. Ruby, et al.
The motion of the parties to dispense with printing the joint appendix is
granted. The motion of Hatteras Yachts Division of Genmar Industries,
Inc. for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted.
No. 89-609. Donald Puckett, et al., Petitioners v. Native Village of
Tyonek, et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this case
expressing the views of the United States.
No. 89-1330. International Organization of Masters, Mates & Pilots,
et al., Petitioners v. Timothy A. Brown. The Solicitor General is invited
to file a brief in this case expressing the views of the United States.
No. 89-645. Michael Milkovich, Sr., Petitioner v. Lorain Journal Co.,
et al. The motion of American Civil Liberties Union, et al. for leave to
file a brief as amici curiae is granted.
No. 89-711. Universal Fabricators, Inc., Petitioner v. Carl Smith, et
al. The motion of respondent Carl Smith for approval of application for
attorney's fees is denied without prejudice to filing the motion in the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
No. 89-1230. City of Chicago, et al., Petitioners v. Walter Friedrich,
etc. The motion of respondent to consolidate this case with No. 89–994,
West Virginia Hospitals, Inc. v. Casey, Governor of Pennsylvania, for
purposes of oral argument, is denied.
No. 89-1399. International Society for Krishna Consciousness of Cal-
ifornia, et al., Petitioners v. Robin George, et al. The application for
stay presented to Justice O'Connor and by her referred to the Court is
granted and it is ordered that execution and enforcement of the judg-
ment of the Court of Appeal of California, Fourth Appellate District,
case No. D007153, entered August 30, 1989, and modified September
29, 1989, and that execution and enforcement of the order of the Supe-
rior Court of California, in and for the County of Orange, case No. 27 75
65, entered March 16, 1990, are stayed pending this Court's action on
the petition for a writ of certiorari. Should the petition for a writ of cer-
tiorari be denied, this stay terminates automatically. In the event the
petition for a writ of certiorari is granted, this stay shall continue pend-
ing issuance of the mandate of this Court.
No. 89-5900. John E. Rust, Petitioner v. Frank O. Gunter, et al. The
motion for appointment of counsel is granted and it is ordered that Al-

544
MONDAY, APRIL 16, 1990
vin J. Bronstein, Esquire, of Washington, D. C., is appointed to serve
as counsel for the petitioner in this case.

TUESDAY, APRIL 17. 1990
571
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
OPINIONS
No. 88-2123. Department of the Treasury, Internal Revenue Serv-
ice, Petitioner 1. Federal Labor Relations Authority, et al. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Co-
lumbia Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Scalia. Dissenting opinion by Justice Brennan
with whom Justice Marshall joins. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Stevens.
No. 88-1213. Employment Division, Department of Human Re-
sources of Oregon, et al., Petitioners . Alfred L. Smith, et al. On writ
of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Oregon. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the Supreme Court for further proceedings not incon-
sistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Scalia. Opin-
ion by Justice O'Connor concurring in the judgment with whom Justice
Brennan, Justice Marshall and Justice Blackmun join as to Parts I and
II, although they do not concur in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Blackmun with whom Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall
join.
No. 88-1595. Kaiser Aluminum & Chemical Corporation, et al., Peti-
tioners. Joseph A. Bonjorno, et al.; and
No. 88-1771. Joseph A. Bonjorno, et al., Petitioners r. Kaiser Alumi-
num & Chemical Corporation, et al. On writs of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judgment affirmed in
part, reversed in part and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opin-
ion by Justice O'Connor. Concurring opinion by Justice Scalia. Dissent-
ing opinion by Justice White with whom Justice Brennan, Justice Mar-
shall, and Justice Blackmun join.
No. 89-431. Yellow Freight System, Inc., Petitioner 1. Colleen Don-
nelly. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Seventh Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Stevens.

572
TUESDAY, APRIL 17, 1990
No. 88-1685. National Labor Relations Board, Petitioner c. Curtin
Matheson Scientific, Inc. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Marshall. Concurring
opinion by the Chief Justice. Dissenting opinion by Justice Blackmun.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Scalia with whom Justice O'Connor and
Justice Kennedy join.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, APRIL 23, 1990
575
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 89-804. Minnesota, Petitioner v. Eli A. Hershberger, et al. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Minnesota. The
petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and
the case is remanded to the Supreme Court of Minnesota for further
consideration in light of Employment Division, Department of Human
Resources of Oregon v. Smith, 494 U.S. (1990). Justice Stevens
and Justice O'Connor dissent.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. —. In Re James L. Martin. The motion to direct the Clerk to
file a petition for a writ of certiorari is denied.
No. Michael Moore, et al., Petitioners v. J. C. Carr, et al. The
motion to direct the Clerk to file an application for an extension of time
and petition for a writ of certiorari, out-of-time, is denied.
No. 65, Original. State of Texas, Plaintiff v. State of New Mexico.
The motion of the River Master for approval of fees is granted and the
River Master is awarded $1,215.00 for the period January 1-March 31,
1990, to be paid equally by the parties.
No. D-857. In the Matter of Disbarment of Robert L. Kay. Disbar-
ment order entered.
No. D-859. In the Matter of Disbarment of Kenneth J. Dawes, Jr.
Kenneth J. Dawes, Jr., of Trenton, New Jersey, having requested to
resign as a member of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name
be stricken from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the
Bar of this Court. The Rule to Show Cause, heretofore issued on Feb-
ruary 20, 1990, is hereby discharged.
No. D–893. In the Matter of Disbarment of John Lewis Aulvin. It is
ordered that John Lewis Aulvin, of Mount Carmel, Illinois, be sus-

576
MONDAY, APRIL 23, 1990
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-894. In the Matter of Disbarment of Bernard Herbert Ostrow-
sky. It is ordered that Bernard Herbert Ostrowsky, of Skokie, Illinois,
be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-895. In the Matter of Disbarment of Louis Carl Dineff. It is
ordered that Louis Carl Dineff, of Summit, Illinois, be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-896. In the Matter of Disbarment of Charles B. Johnson. It is
ordered that Charles B. Johnson, of Pasadena, California, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-897. In the Matter of Disbarment of Alan Mark Hersh. It is
ordered that Alan Mark Hersh, of Beverly Hills, California, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should.
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

for appointment of counsel is granted and it is ordered that Stephen R.
Collins, Esquire, of Phoenix, Arizona, is appointed to serve as counsel
for the respondent in this case.
No. 89-1167. Robert L. Brutsche, Petitioner Linda Cleveland-
Perdue, etc. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this case
expressing the views of the United States.

Wollersheim. The motion of National Council of Churches of Christ in
the U.S.A., et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted.

motion.

MONDAY, APRIL 23, 1990
577
forma pauperis is granted. The motion for appointment of counsel is
granted and it is ordered that Charles S. Hamilton, III, Esquire, of Se-
attle, Washington is appointed to serve as counsel for the appellee Da-
rius Strong in this case for the purpose of filing a brief.
No. 89-6868. Pauline F. Nowak, Petitioner v. Walter S. Trezevant.
The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is de-
nied. Petitioner is allowed until May 14, 1990, within which to pay the
docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in compli-
ance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan and Jus-
tice Marshall, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in Brown v. Her-
ald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928 (1983), we would deny the petition for a writ
of certiorari without reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in
forma pauperis.

addressed to Justice O'Connor and referred to the Court is denied. The
petition for rehearing is denied.
ORDER
It is ordered that the call of the calendar, except for the hearing of
the Flag cases on May 14, 1990, and any other special assignments, be
suspended for the Term upon the conclusion of the arguments in the
cases listed for hearing this week.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Monday, April 30, 1990, until Mon-
day, May 14, 1990.

TUESDAY, APRIL 24, 1990
591
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
'
OPINIONS
No. 88-2102. James Stewart, et al., Petitioners v. Sheldon Abend,
dba Authors Research Company. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice O'Connor.
Opinion by Justice White concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opin-
ion by Justice Stevens with whom the Chief Justice and Justice Scalia
join.
No. 88-1281. Alex Ngiraingas, et al., Petitioners v. Francisco Q.
Sanchez, etc., et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice
Blackmun. Justice Scalia does not join Part II-B of this opinion. Dis-
senting opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall joins.
Justice Kennedy took no part in the consideration or decision of this
case.
No. 88-7146. Jonas H. Whitmore, individually and as next friend of
Ronald Gene Simmons, Petitioner v. Arkansas, et al. On writ of certio-
rari to the Supreme Court of Arkansas. Writ of certiorari dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. See Doremus v. Board of Education, 342 U.S. 429
(1952). Opinion by the Chief Justice. Dissenting opinion by Justice Mar-
shall with whom Justice Brennan joins.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, APRIL 30, 1990
599
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEAL SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 89-6976. Mary Ellen Klein, Appellant v. Massachusetts. Appeal
from the Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal
was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 89-5297. John Nathaniel Hill, Petitioner v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Sixth. Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further consideration in light
of Florida v. Wells, 495 U. S. (1990).
No. 89-5446. Susan J. Kordosky, Petitioner v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Seventh Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit for further consideration in
light of Florida v. Wells, 495 U. S. (1990).
No. 89-6903. Samuel D. Smith, Petitioner v. Missouri. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Missouri. The motion of
petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for
writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the Supreme Court of Missouri for further consideration in
light of McKoy v. North Carolina, 494 U. S. — (1990) and Boyde v.
California, 494 U. S. (1990).

600
-
MONDAY, APRIL 30, 1990
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. Anthony Brown, Petitioner v. United States. The motion.
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis without an affidavit of indigency
executed by the petitioner is denied.
-
No. Stevon Mathis, Petitioner v. United States. The motion for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis without an affidavit of indigency
executed by the petitioner is denied.
No.
Rose Lightfoot, Petitioner v. Louis R. Sullivan, Secretary
of Health and Human Services. The motion to direct the Clerk to file a
petition for a writ of certiorari, out-of-time, is denied.
No. A-700. Kulalani Ltd., et al., Applicant v. Lillian Hagopian
Corey. The application for recall and stay of mandate addressed to Jus-
tice Stevens and referred to the Court is denied.
No. 89-1104. Alcan Foil Products Division of Alcan Aluminum Cor-
poration, Petitioner v. United States. The motion of petitioner to strike
brief of the United States is granted.
No. 89-1322. Oklahoma Tax Commission, Petitioner v. Citizen Band
Potawatomi Indian Tribe of Oklahoma. The Solicitor General is invited
to file a brief in this case expressing the views of the United States.
No. 89-1435. American Railway and Airway Supervisors Associa-
tion, et al., Petitioners v. Soo Line Railroad Company. The Solicitor
General is invited to file a brief in this case expressing the views of the
United States.
No. 89-1433. United States, Appellant v. Shawn D. Eichman, David
Gerald Blalock and Scott W. Tyler; and
No. 89-1434. United States, Appellant v. Mark John Haggerty, Car-
los Garza, Jennifer Proctor Campbell and Darius Allen Strong. The
motion of appellees for divided argument is denied. The motion of
appellees Eichman, Blalock, Tyler, Haggerty, Garza and Campbell for
leave to proceed further herein in forma pauperis is granted.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 89-1149. Coy R. Grogan, et al., Petitioners v. Frank J. Garner,
Jr. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Eighth Circuit granted.

No. 89-386. Port Authority Trans-Hudson Corporation, Petitioner v.
Patrick Feeney; and Port Authority Trans-Hudson Corporation, Peti-
tioner v. Charles T. Foster. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgments affirmed. Opinion
by Justice O'Connor. Opinion by Justice Brennan concurring in part and
concurring in the judgment with whom Justice Marshall, Justice Black-
mun, and Justice Stevens join.
No. 89-258. California, Petitioner v. American Stores Company,
et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Stevens. Concurring opinion by Justice
Kennedy.
No. 89-61. United States, Petitioner v. Filiberto Ojeda Rios, et al.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice White. Concurring opinion by Justice O'Con-
nor with whom Justice Blackmun joins. Dissenting opinion by Justice.
Stevens with whom Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall join.

ORDER IN Pending CasE
No. 89-7307. Bruce Edwin Callins, Petitioner v. Texas. The applica-
tion for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice.
White and by him referred to the Court is denied. Dissenting statement
by Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall. Justice Blackmun and Justice
Stevens would grant the application for stay of execution.



(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, MAY 1, 1990
615
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 89-7359. Jessie Joseph Tafero, Petitioner v. Florida. The appli-
cation for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice
Kennedy and by him referred to the Court is denied. The petition for a
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida is denied. Dissenting
statement by Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall.
ORDER
Ordered:
1. That the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure for the United
States District Courts be, and they hereby are, amended by including
therein amendments to Criminal Rules 5(b), 41(a), 54(b)(4), and (c), and
new Rule 58.
2. That the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of Criminal
Procedure shall take effect on December 1, 1990 and shall govern all
proceedings in criminal cases thereafter commenced and, insofar as just
and practicable, all proceedings in criminal cases then pending.
3. That the Rules of Procedure for the Trial of Misdemeanors before
United States Magistrates, promulgated April 14, 1980, as amended,
are hereby abrogated, effective December 1, 1990.
4. That the Chief Justice be, and he hereby is, authorized to transmit
to the Congress the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of
Criminal Procedure and the abrogation of the Rules of Procedure for
the Trial of Misdemeanors before United States Magistrates in accord-
ance with the provisions of Section 2072 of Title 28, United States
Code.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-760. Robert Lewis Shaw, Applicant v. Bill Armontrout, War-
den. The application for stay of execution of sentence of death pre-
sented to Justice Blackmun and by him referred to the Court is denied.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall
joins. Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens would grant the applica-
tion for stay of execution.

OPINION PER CURIAM
No. A-795. Paul Delo, Superintendent, Potosi Correctional Center,
Applicant v. Winford Stokes. On application to vacate stay of execution
of sentence of death. Application to vacate the stay of execution of the
sentence of death presented to Justice Blackmun and by him referred to
the Court is granted. Opinion per curiam. Concurring opinion by Jus-
tice Kennedy with whom the Chief Justice and Justice Scalia join. Dis-
senting opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall joins
and with whom Justice Blackmun joins as to Parts I, II, and III. Dis-
senting opinion by Justice Stevens with whom Justice Blackmun joins.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-798. Winford L. Stokes, Applicant v. Paul Delo, Superintend-
ent, Potosi Correctional Center. The application for stay of execution of
sentence of death presented to Justice Blackmun and by him referred to
the Court is denied. Dissenting statement by Justice Brennan and Jus-
tice Marshall.



(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MAY 14, 1990
623
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 88-7070. Anthony Gallagher, Petitioner v. United States. On pe-
tition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Third Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Third Circuit for further consideration in light of
United States v. Ojeda Rios, 495 U.S. — (1990).
No. 89-479. Leonardo Benitez and John Leadbeater, Petitioners v.
Port Authority Trans-Hudson Corporation. On petition for writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. The
petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and
the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Third Circuit for further consideration in light of Port Authority Trans-
Hudson Corporation v. Feeney, 495 U.S. (1990).
--

No. 89-6677. Bennie Ree White, Petitioner v. United States. The
motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied.
Petitioner is allowed until June 4, 1990, within which to pay the
docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in compli-
ance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan, Justice
Marshall and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in
Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928, we would deny the petition
for a writ of certiorari without reaching the merits of the motion to pro-
ceed in forma pauperis.
No. 89-7025. Jim Mount, Petitioner v. Melvin F. Gorelick and Roger
Bartels. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma paupe-
ris is denied. Petitioner is allowed until June 4, 1990, within which to
pay the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in
compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan,
Justice Marshall and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the reasons ex-
pressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928, we would deny the

MONDAY, MAY 14, 1990
625
petition for a writ of certiorari without reaching the merits of the mo-
tion to proceed in forma pauperis.
No. 89-7077. Frederick C. Nicolaisen, Petitioner v. Toei Shipping
Company, Ltd., et al. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until June 4, 1990,
within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to sub-
mit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court.
Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For
the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928
(1983), we would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari without
reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.

ORDERS IN Pending CaSES
No. A-811. Johnny Ray Anderson, Applicant v. James A. Collins, Di-
rector, Texas Department of Criminal Justice, Institutional Division.
The application for a certificate of probable cause to appeal to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit presented to Jus-
tice White and by him referred to the Court is denied. Justice Brennan
and Justice Marshall would grant the application.
No. 89-7503. Johnny Ray Anderson, Petitioner v. James A. Collins,
Director, Texas Department of Criminal Justice, Institutional Division.
The application for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to
Justice White and by him referred to the Court is denied. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall joins. Justice
Blackmun and Justice Stevens would grant the application for stay of
execution.

Director, Texas Department of Criminal Justice, Institutional Division.
The application for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to
Justice White and by him referred to the Court is denied. Dissenting

MONDAY, MAY 21, 1990
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be

The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to participate in oral argu-
ment as amicus curiae and for divided argument is granted.

motion for appointment of counsel is granted and it is ordered that Mi-
chael R. Levine, Esquire, of Honolulu, Hawaii, is appointed to serve as
counsel for the respondent in this case.
No. 89-1493. Air Line Pilots Association International, Petitioner v.
Joseph E. O'Neill, et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in
this case expressing the views of the United States.
No. 89-5867. Shirley W. Irwin, Petitioner v. Veterans Administra-
tion, et al. The motion of National Treasury Employees Union for leave
to participate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided argu-
ment is denied.
No. 89-7069. Michelle M. Etlin, Petitioner v. Vladimir N. Etlin; and
In Re Michelle M. Etlin. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until June 11, 1990,
within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to sub-
mit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court,
Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun and Justice Ste-
vens, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co.,
Inc., 464 U.S. 928 (1983), we would deny the petition for a writ of cer-
tiorari without reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in forma
pauperis.
No. 89-7189. Nan Wei, Petitioner v. Delaware. The motion of peti-
tioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner is
allowed until June 11, 1990, within which to pay the docketing fee re-
quired by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in compliance with Rule 33
of the Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall, dis-
senting: For the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464
U.S. 928 (1983), we would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari with-
out reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.

OPINIONS
No. 89-5691. Frasiel L. Hughey, Petitioner v. United States. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth.
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Marshall. Justice White and Justice Kennedy joined
the opinion except as to Part II-C.
No. 88-1932. United States, Petitioner v. German Munoz-Flores. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals.
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Marshall. Opinion by Justice Stevens concurring in
the judgment with whom Justice O'Connor joins. Opinion by Justice
Scalia concurring in the judgment.
No. 88-926. North Dakota, et al., Appellants v. United States. Ap-
peal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for fur-
ther proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Justice
Stevens announced the judgment of the Court and delivered an opinion
in which the Chief Justice, Justice White and Justice O'Connor join.
Opinion announced by the Chief Justice. Opinion by Justice Scalia con-
curring in the judgment. Opinion by Justice Brennan concurring in the
judgment in part and dissenting in part with whom Justice Marshall,
Justice Blackmun and Justice Kennedy join.

667
No. 89-98. Harold Davis, et ux., Petitioners v. United States. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice O'Connor announced by
the Chief Justice.
No. 89-333. California, Petitioner . Federal Energy Regulatory
Commission, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice
O'Connor announced by the Chief Justice.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, MAY 29, 1990
673
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEAL SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 89-1564. James E. Poole, Jr., et al., Appellants . Emma
Gresham, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Northern District of Georgia. The judgment is affirmed.
ORDERS IN Pending CasES
No. A-822. Valentine Bilcik, et al., Applicants v. United States, et
al. The application for a stay of an order of the United States District
Court for the Southern District of New York, dated June 30, 1989, pre-
sented to Justice Marshall and by him referred to the Court is denied.
No. D-819. In the Matter of Disbarment of Timothy Theodore
Chang. Disbarment order entered.
No. D-839. In the Matter of Disbarment of William S.
Higginbotham. Disbarment order entered.
No. D-856. In the Matter of Disbarment of Barry Gerald Sands. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-875. In the Matter of Disbarment of Carl B. Stoner, Jr. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-881. In the Matter of Disbarment of Daniel W. Shoemaker.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-883. In the Matter of Disbarment of Barry H. Singer. Disbar-
ment order entered.
No. D-885. In the Matter of Disbarment of Sheldon Joel Sanders.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-900. In the Matter of Disbarment of John M. Skevin. It is or-
dered that John M. Skevin, of Hackensack, New Jersey, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable.
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

674
TUESDAY, MAY 29, 1990
No. D-901. In the Matter of Disbarment of Bruce A. Olster. It is or-
dered that Bruce A. Olster, of Green Pond, New Jersey, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-902. In the Matter of Disbarment of William A. Metz. It is or-
dered that William A. Metz, of New York City, New York, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-903. In the Matter of Disbarment of Gary L. Hagman. It is
ordered that Gary L. Hagman, of Weatherford, Texas, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 88-1916. Minnesota, Petitioner v. Robert Darren Olson. The mo-
tion of petitioner respecting the mandate and judgment of this Court is
denied.
No. 89-1563. Hank Williams, Jr., et al., Petitioners v. Cathy Yvonne
Stone. The motion of petitioners to defer consideration of the petition
for a writ of certiorari is granted.
No. 89-6702. Louis Carter, Petitioner v. George Nesby, et al. The
motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied.
Petitioner is allowed until June 19, 1990, within which to pay the
docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in compli-
ance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan and Jus-
tice Marshall, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in Brown v. Her-
ald Co., Inc., 464 U. S. 928 (1983), we would deny the petition for a
writ of certiorari without reaching the merits of the motion to proceed
in forma pauperis.
No. 89-7056. Ricky Don Blackmon, Petitioner v. Texas. The applica-
tion for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice
White and by him referred to the Court is granted pending this Court's
action on the petition for a writ of certiorari. Should the petition for a
writ of certiorari be denied, this stay terminates automatically. In the
event the petition for a writ of certiorari is granted, this stay shall re-
main in effect pending the issuance of the mandate of this Court.

TUESDAY, MAY 29, 1990
CERTIORARI GRANTED
675
No. 89-1555. Mark E. Dennis, Petitioner v. Margaret L. Higgins, Di-
rector, Nebraska Department of Motor Vehicles, et al. Petition for writ
of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Nebraska granted.
No. 89–1391. Irving Rust, etc., et al., Petitioners v. Louis W. Sulli-
van, Secretary of Health and Human Services; and
No. 89-1392. New York, et al., Petitioners v. Louis W. Sullivan, Sec-
retary of Health and Human Services. Petitions for writs of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit granted.
The cases are consolidated and a total of one hour is allotted for oral
argument.
No. 89-7272. Ronald Allen Harmelin, Petitioner v. Michigan. The
motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the pe-
tition for a writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Michigan
granted limited to Question III presented by the petition.

OPINIONS
No. 88-1260. Citibank, N.A., Petitioner v. Wells Fargo Asia Lim-
ited. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Kennedy. Concurring opinion by the Chief
Justice. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens.
No. 88-6546. Albert Duro, Petitioner . Edward Reina, Chief of Po-
lice, Salt River Department of Public Safety, Salt River Pima-Maricopa
Indian Community, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Kennedy. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall joins.

"

TUESDAY, MAY 29, 1990
687
No. 89–163. United States, Petitioner . Guadalupe Montalvo-Mu-
rillo. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Tenth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Kennedy. Dissenting opinion by Justice Ste-
vens with whom Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall join.
No. 89-44. Dennis Burnham, Petitioner v. Superior Court of Califor-
nia, County of Marin (Francie Burnham, Real Party in Interest). On
writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeal of California, First Appellate
District. Judgment affirmed. Justice Scalia announced the judgment of
the Court and delivered an opinion in which the Chief Justice and Jus-
tice Kennedy join, and in which Justice White joins with respect to
Parts I, II-A, II-B, and II-C. Opinion by Justice White concurring in
part and concurring in the judgment. Opinion by Justice Brennan con-
curring in the judgment with whom Justice Marshall, Justice Black-
mun, and Justice O'Connor join. Opinion by Justice Stevens concurring
in the judgment.
No. 89-65. Fort Stewart Schools, Petitioner v. Federal Labor Rela-
tions Authority, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by
Justice Scalia. Concurring opinion by Justice Marshall.
No. 88-7194. Arthur Lajuane Taylor, Petitioner v. United States. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth
Circuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Blackmun. Justice Scalia does not join Part II of this
opinion. Opinion by Justice Scalia concurring in part and concurring in
the judgment.
No. 89-156. Pennsylvania Department of Public Welfare, et al., Peti-
tioners v. Edward J. Davenport, et ux. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judgment af-
firmed. Opinion by Justice Marshall. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Blackmun with whom Justice O'Connor joins.
No. 89-255. United States, Petitioner v. Energy Resources Co.,
Inc., et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals.
for the First Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice White.
Justice Blackmun dissents.
No. 89-474. William V. Grady, District Attorney of Dutchess
County, Petitioner v. Thomas J. Corbin. On writ of certiorari to the

by Justice Scalia with whom the Chief Justice and Justice Kennedy

(JOURNAL)
SUNDAY, JUNE 3. 1990
693
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. A-857. Peter Demosthenes, Warden, et al., Applicants . Edwin
and Doris Baal. On application to vacate stay of execution of sentence of
death. The application of the Attorney General of Nevada to vacate the
order of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit,
dated June 2, 1990, staying the execution of sentence of death of
Thomas E. Baal, presented to Justice O'Connor and by her referred to
the Court, is granted. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting opinion by Jus-
tice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall joins. Justice Blackmun and
Justice Stevens dissent and would deny the application to vacate the
stay.



(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JUNE 4, 1990
695
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 89–198. National Treasury Employees Union, Petitioner v.
United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission, et al.; and
No. 89-562. Federal Labor Relations Authority, Petitioner v. Na-
tional Treasury Employees Union, et al. On petitions for writs of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. The
petitions for writs of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated.
and the cases are remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fourth Circuit for further consideration in light of Fort Stewart
Schools v. Federal Labor Relations Authority, 495 U.S. — (1990).
No. 89-736. Federal Labor Relations Authority, Petitioner v. Fort
Knox Dependent Schools, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. The petition for
writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit
for further consideration in light of Fort Stewart Schools v. Federal
Labor Relations Authority, 495 U.S. — (1990).
-
No. 89-1101. United States, Petitioner v. Randall Gene Cunning-
ham. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Ninth Circuit. The motion of respondent for leave to pro-
ceed in forma pauperis is granted. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of Taylor v. United States, 495 U.S. (1990).
No. 89–1177. 11126 Baltimore Blvd., Inc., ta Warwick Books, Peti-
tioner . Prince George's County, Maryland. On petition for writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit.
The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated
and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the

696
MONDAY, JUNE 4, 1990
Fourth Circuit for further consideration in light of FW/PBS, Inc., dba
Paris Adult Bookstore, II v. City of Dallas, 493 U.S. (1990).
No. 89-5743. Donald D. Payton, Petitioner v. United States. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eighth Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eighth Circuit for further consideration in light of Tay-
lor v. United States, 495 U.S. (1990).
No. 89-5938. Eddie Lucio Garcia, Petitioner v. United States. On pe-
tition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further consideration in light of Taylor
v. United States, 495 U.S. (1990).
-
No. 89-6995. Odie Lee Jordan, Petitioner v. United States. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eighth Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eighth Circuit for further consideration in light of Tay-
lor v. United States, 495 U.S. (1990).

MONDAY, JUNE 4, 1990
697
No. D-892. In the Matter of Disbarment of John A. Shorter, Jr. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-897. In the Matter of Alan Mark Hersh. Alan Mark Hersh, of
Beverly Hills, California, having requested to resign as a member of
the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name be stricken from the
roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the Bar of this Court. The
Rule to Show Cause, heretofore issued on April 23, 1990, is hereby
discharged.
No. D-904. In the Matter of Disbarment of Thomas Lawrence Root.
It is ordered that Thomas Lawrence Root, of Washington, D.C., be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-905. In the Matter of Disbarment of Larry L. Hanna. It is or-
dered that Larry L. Hanna, of Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 109, Original. States of Oklahoma and Texas, Plaintiffs v. State
of New Mexico. The motion of the Special Master for allowance of com-
pensation and reimbursement of expenses is granted and the Special
Master is awarded $61,292.54 for the period September 1, 1989,
through January 31, 1990-one-third to be paid by each party.
No. 89-532. Peat Marwick Main & Co., Petitioner v. W. David
Holloway, et al. The motion of respondents to retax costs is denied.
No. 89-839. Arizona, Petitioner v. Oreste C. Fulminante. The motion
of Americans for Effective Law Enforcement, Inc., et al. for leave to
file a brief as amici curiae is granted. The motion of the Solicitor Gen-
eral for leave to participate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for
divided argument is granted.
No. 89-1145. Linda McCracken, Petitioner v. City of College Park,
Georgia, et al. The motion of respondents for attorney's fees is denied.
No. 89-1421. Marvin Powell, et al., Petitioners v. National Football
League, et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this case
expressing the views of the United States.
No. 89-7043. Harvey Kudler, Petitioner v. Judicial Council of the
Second Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until June 25, 1990, within
which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a
petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice

698
MONDAY, JUNE 4, 1990
Brennan and Justice Marshall, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in
Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928 (1983), we would deny the pe-
tition for a writ of certiorari without reaching the merits of the motion
to proceed in forma pauperis.
No. 89-7170. Chimurenga K.S. Jenga, et ux., Petitioners v. Clinton
H. Deveaux. The motion of petitioners for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis is denied. Petitioners are allowed until June 25, 1990, within
which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a
petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice
Brennan and Justice Marshall, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in
Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928 (1983), we would deny the pe-
tition for a writ of certiorari without reaching the merits of the motion
to proceed in forma pauperis.

perintendent, Georgia Diagnostic & Classification Center. The motion

writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Elev-
enth Circuit are granted. In addition to the questions presented by the
petition, the parties are requested to brief and argue the following
question:

MONDAY, JUNE 4, 1990
699
"Must the State demonstrate that a claim was deliberately aban-
doned in an earlier petition for a writ of habeas corpus in order to estab-
lish that inclusion of that claim in a subsequent habeas petition consti-
tutes abuse of the writ?"

No. 87-6927. Alexis Hamilton, as natural mother and next friend of
James Edward Smith, Petitioner v. Texas;
No. 88–1213. Employment Division, Department of Human Re-
sources of Oregon, et al., Petitioners v. Alfred L. Smith, et al.;
No. 88-5986. Clyde Osborne, Appellant v. Ohio;
No. 89-1319. Mark Tarka, Petitioner v. G. Charles Franklin, et al.;
No. 89-1334. Jerome B. Rosenthal, Petitioner v. J. M. Young, et al.;
No. 89-1341. Maria Graciela Ramirez, Petitioner v. Transamerican
Natural Gas Corp., et al.;
No. 89-1382. In Re James Freed, Petitioner;
No. 89-5737. Charles Troy Coleman, Petitioner v. James Saffle,
Warden, et al.;
No. 89-6302. Harold G. Williams, Petitioner v. Ralph Kemp,
Warden;
No. 89-6818. In Re Floyd Hicks, Petitioner;
No. 89-6835. James Watts, Petitioner v. O. S. Foster, et al.;
No. 89-6869. Eunice Justice, Petitioner v. Ohio, et al.; and
No. 89-6888. Vinod Gulati, Petitoner v. United States. The petitions
for rehearing are denied.
No. 86-1964. James G. Wallace, Petitioner v. Arizona. The motion of
petitioner for leave to proceed further herein in forma pauperis is
granted. The motion for leave to file a petition for rehearing is denied.
Justice O'Connor took no part in the consideration or decision of these
motions.

MONDAY, JUNE 4, 1990
709
No. 89-5629. James Granvil Wallace, Petitioner v. Arizona. The peti-
tion for rehearing is denied. Justice O'Connor took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this petition.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Monday, June 4, 1990, until Mon-
day, June 11, 1990.

OPINIONS
No. 88-1972. Illinois, Petitioner v. Lloyd Perkins. On writ of certio-
rari to the Appellate Court of Illinois, Fifth District. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Appellate Court for further proceed-
ings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Kennedy. Opinion by Justice Brennan concurring in the judgment. Dis-
senting opinion by Justice Marshall.
No. 88-325. American Trucking Associations, Inc., et al., Petitioners
2. Maurice Smith, Director, Arkansas Highway and Transportation De-
partment, et al. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Arkan-
sas. Judgment affirmed in part, reversed in part and case remanded to
the Supreme Court for further proceedings not inconsistent with the
opinion of this Court. Justice O'Connor announced the judgment of the
Court and delivered an opinion in which the Chief Justice, Justice
White, and Justice Kennedy join. Opinion by Justice Scalia concurring
in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens with whom Jus-
tice Brennan, Justice Marshall and Justice Blackmun join.
No. 88-1597. Board of Education of the Westside Community
Schools, etc., et al., Petitioners 2. Bridget C. Mergens, by and through
her next friend, Daniel N. Mergens, et al. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Judgment af-
firmed. Justice O'Connor delivered the opinion of the Court except as to
Part III. Opinion by Justice Kennedy concurring in part and concurring
in the judgment with whom Justice Scalia joins. Opinion by Justice
Marshall concurring in the judgment with whom Justice Brennan joins.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens.

MONDAY, JUNE 4, 1990
713
No. 88-1775. Gary E. Peel, Petitioner v. Attorney Registration and
Disciplinary Commission of Illinois. On writ of certiorari to the
Supreme Court of Illinois. Judgment reversed and case remanded to
the Supreme Court for further proceedings not inconsistent with the
opinion of this Court. Justice Stevens announced the judgment of the
Court and delivered an opinion in which Justice Brennan, Justice Black-
mun, and Justice Kennedy join. Opinion by Justice Marshall concurring
in the judgment with whom Justice Brennan joins. Dissenting opinion
by Justice White. Dissenting opinion by Justice O'Connor with whom
the Chief Justice and Justice Scalia join.
No. 88-7164. Terry Brice Horton, Petitioner v. California. On writ of
certiorari to the Court of Appeal of California, Sixth Appellate District.
Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall joins.
No. 89-601. Commissioner, Immigration and Naturalization Service,
et al., Petitioners v. Marie Lucie Jean, et al. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. Judgment af-
firmed. Opinion by Justice Stevens.
No. 89-152. Vera M. English, Petitioner v. General Electric Com-
pany. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fourth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Blackmun.
No. 89-393. Harry P. Begier, Jr., etc., Petitioner v. Internal Reve-
nue Service. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Third Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Marshall.
Opinion by Justice Scalia concurring in the judgment.
No. 88-192. McKesson Corporation, Petitioner v. Division of Alco-
holic Beverages and Tobacco, Department of Business Regulation of
Florida, et al. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Supreme Court for fur-
ther proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opin-
ion by Justice Brennan.
No. 88-1905. Eddie Keller, et al., Petitioners v. State Bar of Califor-
nia, et al. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of California.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Supreme Court for fur-
ther proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opin-
ion by the Chief Justice.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JUNE 11, 1990
719
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 89-510. Larry R. Meachum, Commissioner, Connecticut Depart-
ment of Corrections, Petitioner v. Wayne B. Alexander. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second
Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is
vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Second Circuit for further consideration in light of Illinois v.
Perkins, 495 U.S. (1990).
No. 89-641. Richard Garnett, etc., et al., Petitioners v. Renton
School District No. 403, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The petition for
writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit
for further consideration in light of Board of Education of the Westside
Community Schools v. Mergens, 495 U.S. (1990). Justice Stevens
dissents.
No. 89-1320. Florida, Petitioner v. Charles Lewis Burr. On petition.
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida. The motion of
respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The peti-
tion for a writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the
case is remanded to the Supreme Court of Florida for further consider-
ation in light of Dowling v. United States, 493 U.S. (1990). Dis-
senting opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall joins.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens. Justice Blackmun dissents.
No. 89-5900. John E. Rust, Petitioner v. Frank O. Gunter, et al. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth
Circuit. The motion of Alvin J. Bronstein, Esquire, to withdraw as
counsel for the petitioner is granted. The judgment is vacated and the
case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth
Circuit for further consideration in light of the representations made

720
MONDAY, JUNE 11, 1990
by counsel for petitioner appointed by the Court in his motion to with-
draw as counsel filed May 22, 1990, the response to that motion filed by
respondent May 30, 1990, and petitioner's motion for appointment of
counsel filed June 4, 1990. The motion of petitioner for appointment of
new counsel is denied as moot. Concurring opinion by Justice Stevens.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. D-807. In the Matter of James Cally. It having been reported to
the Court that James J. Cally has died, The Rule to Show Cause, here-
tofore, issued on September 25, 1989, is hereby discharged.
No. D-858. In the Matter of Disbarment of John R. Louden. Disbar-
ment order entered.
No. D-884. In the Matter of Disbarment of Richard J. Sanna. Disbar-
ment order entered.
No. D-886. In the Matter of Disbarment of Frank Moses McCann.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-888. In the Matter of Disbarment of Ronald J. Raben. Disbar-
ment order entered.
No. D-906. In the Matter of Disbarment of Jonathan Erickson. It is
ordered that Jonathan Erickson, of Corning, New York, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-907. In the Matter of Disbarment of Irvin F. Richman. It is
ordered that Irvin F. Richman, of Chicago, Illinois, be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-908. In the Matter of Disbarment of Bernard S. Neistein. It is
ordered that Bernard S. Neistein, of Chicago, Illinois, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-909. In the Matter of Disbarment of Clyde P. Martin, Jr. It is
ordered that Clyde P. Martin, Jr., of New Orleans, Louisiana, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-910. In the Matter of Disbarment of Fredric Fedje Hendrick-
son. It is ordered that Fredric Fedje Hendrickson, of Sioux Falls,

MONDAY, JUNE 11, 1990
721
South Dakota, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and
that a rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show
cause why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this
Court.
No. D-911. In the Matter of Disbarment of John M. Badalian. It is
ordered that John M. Badalian, of Shaker Heights, Ohio, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 89-907. County of Los Angeles and Ronald Black, Commander of
the Los Angeles County Men's Central Jail, Petitioners v. Josefina
Cabrales. The motion of respondent for award of attorneys' fees is de-
nied without prejudice to renewal of the motion in the United States
District Court for the Central District of California.
No. 89–1027. Norfolk and Western Railway Company, et al., Peti-
tioners v. American Train Dispatchers Association, et al.; and
No. 89-1028. CSX Transportation, Inc., Petitioner v. Brotherhood of
Railway Carmen, et al. Further consideration of the motion of respond-
ents American Train Dispatchers' Association, et al. to dismiss is de-
ferred for 120 days. Further briefing in this case is suspended for 120
days.

OPINIONS
Marvin M. Klein
No. 88-1943. Office of Personnel Management, Petitioner v. Charles
Richmond. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Federal Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Justice Kennedy. Concurring opinion by Jus-
tice White with whom Justice Blackmun joins. Opinion by Justice Ste-
vens concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice Mar-
shall with whom Justice Brennan joins.
No. 89-275. Cooter & Gell, Petitioner . Hartmarx Corporation, et
al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment affirmed in part,
reversed in part and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Justice O'Connor. Opinion by Justice Stevens concurring in part and
dissenting in part.
No. 89-542. Rudy Perpich, Governor of Minnesota, et al., Petitioners
1. Department of Defense, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Justice Stevens.
No. 89-5383. Mark Howlett, a minor, by and through Elizabeth.
Howlett, his mother, natural guardian and next friend, Petitioner v.
Scott Rose, as Superintendent of Schools for the Pinellas County, Flor-
ida. et al. On writ of certiorari to the District Court of Appeal of Flor-
ida. Second District. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Dis-
trict Court of Appeal for further proceedings not inconsistent with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Stevens.
No. 89-789. Alabama, Petitioner v. Vanessa Rose White. On writ of
certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Alabama. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Court of Criminal Appeals for further

734
MONDAY, JUNE 11, 1990
proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Justice White. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens with whom Jus-
tice Brennan and Justice Marshall join.
No. 89–1433. United States, Appellant v. Shawn D. Eichman, David
Gerald Blalock and Scott W. Tyler. Appeal from the United States Dis-
trict Court for the District of Columbia; and
No. 89-1434. United States, Appellant v. Mark John Haggerty, Car-
los Garza, Jennifer Proctor Campbell and Darius Allen Strong. Appeal
from the United States District Court for the Western District of
Washington. Judgments affirmed. Opinion by Justice Brennan. Dis-
senting opinion by Justice Stevens with whom the Chief Justice, Justice
White and Justice O'Connor join.
