(JOURNAL)
THURSDAY, JUNE 14, 1990
741
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice Scalia,
and Justice Kennedy.
OPINIONS
No. 87-2048. Texaco Inc., Petitioner v. Ricky Hasbrouck, dba Rick's
Texaco, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Ste-
vens. Opinion by Justice White concurring in the result. Opinion by
Justice Scalia concurring in the judgment with whom Justice Kennedy
joins.
No. 89-369. General Motors Corporation, Petitioner v. United
States. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the First Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Blackmun.
No. 88-2043. L. Douglas Wilder, Governor of Virginia, et al., Peti-
tioners v. Virginia Hospital Association. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment af-
firmed. Opinion by Justice Brennan. Dissenting opinion by the Chief
Justice with whom Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, and Justice Ken-
nedy join.
No. 88-1897. Michigan Department of State Police, et al., Petitioners
v. Rick Sitz, et al. On writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Michi-
gan. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by the Chief Justice. Opinion by Justice Blackmun concurring
in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice Brennan with whom
Justice Marshall joins. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens with
whom Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall join as to Parts I and II.
No. 89-535. Louis W. Sullivan, Secretary of Health and Human
Services, Petitioner v. Elizabeth Stroop, et al. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by the
Chief Justice. Dissenting opinion by Justice Blackmun with whom Jus-

742
THURSDAY, JUNE 14, 1990
tice Brennan and Justice Marshall join. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Stevens.
Adjourned until Monday, June 18, 1990 at 10 a.m.

(JOURNAL)
SATURDAY, JUNE 16, 1990
743
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-901. John Edward Swindler, Applicant 1. A. L. Lockhart, Di-
rector, Arkansas Department of Correction. The application for stay of
execution of sentence of death presented to Justice Blackmun and by
him referred to the Court is denied. Dissenting statement by Justice
Brennan and Justice Marshall.



(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JUNE 18, 1990
745
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 89-1221. Michigan, Petitioner v. Terrance Moore. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Michigan. The petition for
writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the Court of Appeals of Michigan for further consideration
in light of Horton v. California, 496 U.S.
(1990).
No. 89-1701. Ronald Masters, Petitioner v. Daniel International Cor-
poration. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of English v. General Electric Company, 496 U.S.
(1990).
-
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. Earlene Polyak, Petitioner v. Thomas Stack, et al. The mo-
tion to direct the Clerk to docket an appeal from the United States Dis-
trict Court for the Middle District of Tennessee is denied.
-.
No. Eddie William Finney, Petitioner v. Ralph Kemp, Warden,
Georgia Diagnostic and Classification Center. The motion for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis without an affidavit of indigency executed
by the petitioner is granted.
No. A-875. Phillip Seelig, President of the Correction Officers
Benevolent Association of the City of New York, et al., Applicants v.
Richard J. Koehler, Correction Commissioner of the City of New York,
et al. The application for stay of enforcement of random urinalysis drug-
testing program presented to Justice Marshall and by him referred to
the Court is denied.
No. D-872. In the Matter of Disbarment of Thomas M. Joyce. Dis-
barment order entered.

746
MONDAY, JUNE 18, 1990
No. D-877. In the Matter of Disbarment of Jack B. Solerwitz. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-880. In the Matter of Disbarment of Hesper A. Jackson, Jr.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-890. In the Matter of Disbarment of Mac W. Hancock, III.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-893. In the Matter of John Lewis Aulvin. John Lewis Aulvin,
of Mount Carmel, Illinois, having requested to resign as a member of
the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name be stricken from the
roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the Bar of this Court. The
Rule to Show Cause, heretofore issued on April 23, 1990, is hereby
discharged.
No. D-896. In the Matter of Charles B. Johnson. Charles B. Johnson,
of Pasadena, California, having requested to resign as a member of the
Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name be stricken from the roll of
attorneys admitted to practice before the Bar of this Court. The Rule to
Show Cause, heretofore issued on April 23, 1990, is hereby discharged.
No. D-912. In the Matter of Disbarment of Frederick Brockmeier,
IV. It is ordered that Frederick Brockmeier, IV, of Southgate, Ken-
tucky, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a
rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause
why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 89-1283. Arcadia, Ohio, et al., Petitioners v. Ohio Power Com-
pany, et al. The motion of the Acting Solicitor General for leave to par-
ticipate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument is
granted.
No. 89-1667. Jay Palmer, et al., Petitioners v. BRG of Georgia, Inc.,
et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this case express-
ing the views of the United States.
No. 89-5120. Michael Owen Perry, Petitioner v. Louisiana. The mo-
tion of American Psychiatric Association, et al. for leave to participate
in oral argument as amici curiae and for divided argument is denied.
No. 89-7063. Burton R. Landes, Petitioner v. Robert H. Joost. The
motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied.
Petitioner is allowed until July 9, 1990, within which to pay the dock-
eting fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in compliance
with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan, Justice Mar-
shall and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in

MONDAY, JUNE 18, 1990
747
Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U. S. 928 (1983), we would deny the
petition for a writ of certiorari without reaching the merits of the mo-
tion to proceed in forma pauperis.
No. 89-7300. Arthur Britton, Sr., Petitioner 1. Central Bank. The
motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied.
Petitioner is allowed until July 9, 1990, within which to pay the
docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in compli-
ance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan, Justice
Marshall and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in
Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U. S. 928 (1983), we would deny the
petition for a writ of certiorari without reaching the merits of the mo-
tion to proceed in forma pauperis.

et al., Petitioners v. Timothy A. Brown. Petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit granted.

certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit
granted.

No. 89-7370. Moshe Gozlon-Peretz, Petitioner v. United States. The
motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted.
The petition for a writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Third Circuit granted limited to the following question:
Whether the mandatory minimum terms of supervised release required
by the Anti-Drug Abuse Act of 1986 became effective for offenses com-
mitted on or after the date of enactment, October 27, 1986.

MONDAY, JUNE 18, 1990
OPINIONS
No. 89–243. Eli Lilly and Company, Petitioner v. Medronic, Inc. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal
Circuit. Judgment affirmed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Scalia. Dissenting opinion by Justice Kennedy with
whom Justice White joins. Justice O'Connor took no part in the consid-
eration or decision of this case.
No. 89-390. Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, Petitioner v.
LTV Corporation, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Blackmun. Opinion by
Justice White concurring in part and dissenting in part with whom Jus-
tice O'Connor joins. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens.
No. 89-504. Louis W. Sullivan, Secretary of Health and Human
Services, Petitioner v. Marilyn Finkelstein. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
White. Opinion by Justice Scalia concurring in part. Opinion by Justice
Blackmun concurring in the judgment.
No. 89-213. Pennsylvania, Petitioner 2. Inocencio Muniz. On writ of
certiorari to the Superior Court of Pennsylvania, Harrisburg Office.
Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Superior Court for further
proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Justice
Brennan delivered the opinion of the Court except as to Part III-C.
Opinion by the Chief Justice concurring in part, concurring in the result
in part, and dissenting in part with whom Justice White, Justice Black-
mun and Justice Stevens join. Opinion by Justice Marshall concurring in
part and dissenting in part.

(JOURNAL)
THURSDAY, JUNE 21, 1990
767
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice Scalia,
and Justice Kennedy.
OPINIONS
No. 88-2109. Kansas and Missouri, etc., Petitioners v. Utilicorp.
United Inc. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Tenth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Kennedy.
Dissenting opinion by Justice White with whom Justice Brennan, Jus-
tice Marshall, and Justice Blackmun join.
No. 89-5809. Robert Sawyer, Petitioner v. Larry Smith, Interim
Warden. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fifth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Kennedy. Dis-
senting opinion by Justice Marshall with whom Justice Brennan joins,
Justice Blackmun joins as to Parts I-IV, and Justice Stevens joins as to
Parts I-III.
No. 88-2018. Illinois, Petitioner v. Edward Rodriguez. On writ of
certiorari to the Appellate Court of Illinois, First District. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Appellate Court for further pro-
ceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Jus-
tice Scalia. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall with whom Justice
Brennan and Justice Stevens join.
No. 89-530. Portland Golf Club, Petitioner v. Commissioner of Inter-
nal Revenue. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice
Blackmun. Opinion by Justice Kennedy concurring in part and concur-
ring in the judgment with whom Justice O'Connor and Justice Scalia
join.
No. 89-624. Maislin Industries, U.S., Inc., et al., Petitioners . Pri-
mary Steel, Inc. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Eighth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to
the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Brennan. Concurring opinion
by Justice Scalia. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens with whom the
Chief Justice joins.
No. 88-1872. Cynthia Rutan, et al., Petitioners . Republican Party
of Illinois, et al.; and

768
THURSDAY, JUNE 21, 1990
No. 88-2074. Mark Frech, et al., Petitioners 2. Cynthia Rutan, et al.
On writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Seventh Circuit. Judgment affirmed in part, reversed in part, and cases
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Brennan. Concurring
opinion by Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by Justice Scalia with
whom the Chief Justice and Justice Kennedy join, and with whom Jus-
tice O'Connor joins as to Parts II and III.
No. 89-645. Michael Milkovich, Sr., Petitioner v. Lorain Journal Co.,
et al. On writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Lake
County. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by the Chief Justice. Dissenting opinion by Justice Brennan
with whom Justice Marshall joins.
No. 89-742. James A. Collins, Director, Texas Department of Crimi-
nal Justice, Institutional Division, Petitioner v. Carroll F. Youngblood.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals.
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by the Chief Justice. Opinion by Justice Stevens concurring in
the judgment with whom Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall join.
✗
Adjourned until Monday, June 25, 1990 at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JUNE 25, 1990
769
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally. On Wednesday,
June 27, 1990, the Court will announce all of the remaining opinions
ready during the Term of the Court."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 89-6985. Horacio Alvarado, Petitioner v. United States. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment
is vacated and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Second Circuit for further consideration in light of the position as-
serted by the Solicitor General in his brief for the United States filed
May 21, 1990. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting opinion by the Chief Jus-
tice with whom Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy
join.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 89-761. Edward E. Rice, Petitioner v. Ohio Department of
Transportation, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. The petition for writ of
certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further
consideration in light of Rutan v. Republican Party of Illinois, 497
U.S. — (1990).
No. 89-936. INF, Ltd., Petitioner 1. Spectro Alloys Corp. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eighth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eighth Circuit for further consideration in light of
Maislin Industries, U.S., Inc. v. Primary Steel, Inc., 497 U.S.
(1990).
No. 89-944. Georgia, Petitioner v. Thomas D. Stewart, et ux. On pe-
tition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Georgia. The peti-

770
MONDAY, JUNE 25, 1990
tion for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the
case is remanded to the Court of Appeals of Georgia for further consid-
eration in light of Illinois v. Rodriguez, 497 U.S.
Stevens dissents.
-
(1990). Justice
No. 89-1575. Gaetano Vastola, et al., Petitioners v. United States.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Third Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit for further consideration in light
of United States v. Ojeda-Rios, 495 U.S. (1990).
No. 89-5849. Bruce Messer and Timothy P'Simer, Petitioners v.
Fran Curci, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. The motion of petitioners for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certio-
rari are granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further
consideration in light of Rutan v. Republican Party of Illinois, 497
U.S. - (1990).
-
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. D-868. In the Matter of Disbarment of Gerard E. Molony. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-871. In the Matter of Disbarment of William Herbert Price.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-885. In the Matter of Disbarment of Sheldon Joel Sanders.
The order entered May 29, 1990 is amended to read as follows: It having
been reported to the Court that Sheldon Joel Sanders, of Lido Beach,
New York, has been disbarred from the practice of law by the Appel-
late Division, Supreme Court of New York, Second Judicial Depart-
ment, and this Court by order of March 26, 1990, having suspended the
said Sheldon Joel Sanders from the practice of law in this Court and
directed that a rule issue requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred;
And it appearing that the said rule was duly issued and served upon
the respondent and that a response has been filed;
It is ordered that the said Sheldon Joel Sanders be disbarred from
the practice of law in this Court and that his name be stricken from the
roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the Bar of this Court.
No. D-895. In the Matter of Disbarment of Louis Carl Dineff. Dis-
barment order entered.

MONDAY, JUNE 25, 1990
771
No. D-913. In the Matter of Disbarment of Isaiah White Williams. It
is ordered that Isaiah White Williams, of St. Petersburg, Florida, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-914. In the Matter of Disbarment of William W. Watkins, Sr.
It is ordered that William W. Watkins, Sr., of Columbia, South Caro-
lina, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 89–1391. Irving Rust, etc., et al., Petitioners v. Louis W. Sulli-
van, Secretary of Health and Human Services; and
No. 89-1392. New York, et al., Petitioners v. Louis W. Sullivan, Sec-
retary of Health and Human Services. The motion of Alan Ernest for
leave to represent children unborn and born alive is denied. The motion
of Legal Defense for Unborn Children for leave to file a brief as amicus
curiae is denied.
No. 89-1947. John Remington Graham, Petitioner v. William J.
Wernz, etc. The application for stay addressed to Justice Brennan and
referred to the Court is denied.
No. 89-5900. John E. Rust, Petitioner v. Frank O. Gunter, et al. The
motion of Alvin J. Bronstein for reimbursement of travel expenses is
granted.
CERTIORARI GRANTED

nications Enterprises, Inc. and Michael Shipp. Petition for writ of cer-

granted.
No. 89-1541. Elizabeth Dole, Secretary of Labor, Petitioner v. Occu-
pational Safety and Health Review Commission, et al. Petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit
granted.

Petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Okla-
homa denied. Dissenting opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice
Marshall joins.
No. 89-7387. Carl Doughty and Larry Wilson, Petitioners v. Board
of County Commissioners for the County of Weld, et al. The petition for
a writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth
Circuit before judgment is denied.
PROHIBITION DENIED
No. 89-7347. In Re Jackie Brooks. The petition for writ of prohi-
bition is denied.
REHEARINGS DENIED
No. 89-81. Miriam Wilson, et al., Petitioners v. Michael Lane, Direc-
tor, Illinois Department of Corrections;
No. 89-1465. Daniel Kozak, Petitioner v. United States Department
of Agriculture;
No. 89-6914. David Meyers, Petitioner v. Indiana;
No. 89-6954. Kenneth Earl Magwood, Petitioner v. Alabama; and
No. 89-7028. Louis Edward Fryhover, Petitioner 1. United States.
The petitions for rehearing are denied.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Monday, June 25, 1990, until
Wednesday, June 27, 1990.

OPINIONS
No. 88-805. Ohio, Appellant v. Akron Center for Reproductive
Health, et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
Sixth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Justice Kennedy announced the judgment of the Court and de-
livered the opinion of the Court with respect to Parts I, II, III, and IV,
and an opinion with respect to Part V, in which the Chief Justice, Jus-
tice White, and Justice Scalia join. Concurring opinion by Justice
Scalia. Opinion by Justice Stevens concurring in part and concurring in
the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice Blackmun with whom Jus-
tice Brennan and Justice Marshall join.
No. 88-1125. Jane Hodgson, et al., Petitioners . Minnesota, et al.;
and
No. 88-1309. Minnesota, et al., Petitioners . Jane Hodgson, et al.
On writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eighth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Justice Stevens announced the
judgment of the Court and delivered the opinion of the Court with re-
spect to Parts I, II, IV, and VII, an opinion with respect to Part III in
which Justice Brennan joins, an opinion with respect to Parts V and VI

786
MONDAY, JUNE 25, 1990
in which Justice O'Connor joins, and a dissenting opinion with respect
to Part VIII. Opinion by Justice O'Connor concurring in part and con-
curring in the judgment in part. Opinion by Justice Marshall concurring
in part, concurring in the judgment in part, and dissenting in part with
whom Justice Brennan and Justice Blackmun join. Opinion by Justice
Scalia concurring in the judgment in part and dissenting in part. Opin-
ion by Justice Kennedy concurring in the judgment in part and dissent-
ing in part with whom the Chief Justice, Justice White, and Justice
Scalia join.
No. 74, Original. State of Georgia, Plaintiff v. State of South Caro-
lina. On Exceptions to Reports of the Special Master. Exceptions of
South Carolina overruled. Exception of Georgia to the Special Master's
use of right-angle principle sustained. Other exceptions of Georgia
overruled. Recommendations of the Special Master in his two reports,
and as to which no exception has been taken, adopted (subject to res-
ervation expressed in n. 7). Each recommendation of the Special Master
and as to which an Exception has been advanced but overruled,
adopted. Parties directed promptly to prepare appropriate proposed
decree in line with these conclusions and submit directly to this Court
for review and consideration. No costs allowed. Court retains jurisdic-
tion to entertain such further proceedings as from time to time may be
necessary or advisable to effectuate the forthcoming decree and the
rights of the respective parties. Opinion by Justice Blackmun. Opinion
by Justice White dissenting in part with whom Justice Marshall joins.
Opinion by Justice Stevens dissenting in part with whom Justice Scalia
joins. Opinion by Justice Scalia dissenting in part with whom Justice
Kennedy joins. Opinion by Justice Kennedy dissenting in part with
whom the Chief Justice joins.
No. 88-2041. Everett A. Sisson, Petitioner . Burton B. Ruby, et al.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sev-
enth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Marshall. Opinion by Justice Scalia concur-
ring in the judgment with whom Justice White joins.
No. 88–1503. Nancy Beth Cruzan, by her parents and co-guardians,
Lester L. Cruzan, et ux., Petitioners v. Director, Missouri Department
of Health, et al. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Missouri.
Judgment affirmed. Opinion by the Chief Justice. Concurring opinion
by Justice O'Connor. Concurring opinion by Justice Scalia. Dissenting

MONDAY, JUNE 25, 1990
787
opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall and Justice
Blackmun join. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens.

TUESDAY, JUNE 26, 1990
789
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 89-7838. Alexzene Hamilton, as Natural Mother and Next
Friend to James Edward Smith, Petitioner v. Texas; and
No. 89-7842. Alexzene Hamilton, as Natural Mother and Next
Friend to James Edward Smith, Petitioner v. James A. Collins, Direc-
tor, Texas Department of Criminal Justice, Institutional Division. The
applications for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Jus-
tice White and by him referred to the Court are denied. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall joins. Justice
Blackmun and Justice Stevens dissent and would grant the applications
for stay.



(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY. JUNE 27. 1990
791
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
OPINIONS
No. 89-640. Manuel Lujan, Jr., Secretary of the Interior, et al., Peti-
tioners v. National Wildlife Federation, et al. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for fur-
ther proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Justice Scalia. Dissenting opinion by Justice Blackmun with whom
Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall and Justice Stevens join.
No. 88-2031. United States, Petitioner v. Marsha B. Kokinda, et al.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fourth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Justice O'Connor announced the judgment of the Court and de-
livered an opinion in which the Chief Justice, Justice White and Justice
Scalia join. Opinion by Justice Kennedy concurring in the judgment.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall and
Justice Stevens join and with whom Justice Blackmun joins as to Part I.
No. 89-189. Samuel A. Lewis, Director, Arizona Department of Cor-
rections, et al., Petitioners v. Jimmie Wayne Jeffers. On writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judg-
ment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Justice O'Connor. Dissenting opinion by Justice Brennan with whom
Justice Marshall joins in this case and in No. 88-7351, Walton v. Ari-
zona, post. Dissenting opinion by Justice Blackmun with whom Justice
Brennan, Justice Marshall and Justice Stevens join.
No. 89–260. Idaho, Petitioner v. Laura Lee Wright. On writ of cer-
tiorari to the Supreme Court of Idaho. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by
Justice O'Connor. Dissenting opinion by Justice Kennedy with whom
the Chief Justice, Justice White and Justice Blackmun join.
No. 89-478. Maryland, Petitioner v. Sandra Ann Craig. On writ of
certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Maryland. Judgment vacated and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings not in-

792
WEDNESDAY, JUNE 27, 1990
consistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice O'Connor.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Scalia with whom Justice Brennan, Jus-
tice Marshall and Justice Stevens join.
No. 88-7351. Jeffrey Alan Walton, Petitioner v. Arizona. On writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Arizona. Judgment affirmed. Justice
White announced the judgment of the Court and delivered the opinion
of the Court with respect to Parts I, II, and V, and an opinion in Parts
III and IV in which the Chief Justice, Justice O'Connor and Justice
Kennedy join. Opinion by Justice Scalia concurring in part and concur-
ring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice Brennan with
whom Justice Marshall joins in this case and in No. 89-189, Lewis v.
Jeffers, ante. Dissenting opinion by Justice Blackmun with whom Jus-
tice Brennan, Justice Marshall and Justice Stevens join. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Stevens.
No. 89-453. Metro Broadcasting, Inc., Petitioner v. Federal Commu-
nications Commission, et al.; and
No. 89-700. Astroline Communications Company Limited Partner-
ship, Petitioner v. Shurberg Broadcasting of Hartford, Inc., et al. On
writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District
of Columbia Circuit. The judgment in No. 89-453 is affirmed, the judg-
ment in No. 89-700 is reversed and the cases are remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Justice Brennan. Concurring opinion by Jus-
tice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by Justice O'Connor with whom the
Chief Justice, Justice Scalia and Justice Kennedy join. Dissenting opin-
ion by Justice Kennedy with whom Justice Scalia joins.
The Chief Justice said:
"I am authorized to announce that all cases submitted to the Court
for decision have been acted upon by the Court. All other matters
scheduled for Conference today will be released on an Order List
Thursday, June 28, 1990. Accordingly, it is ordered that those cases re-
maining on the docket, but not ready for consideration, are continued to
the session of the Court beginning October 1, 1990.
The Court will be in recess from today until the first Monday in Octo-
ber 1990, at which time the October 1989 Term of the Court will be ad-
journed and the October 1990 Term of the Court will begin as provided
by statute on the first Monday in October.
In closing, on behalf of each Justice, I thank each member of the
Supreme Court staff for their continued dedication to the work of the
Court during the Term. This dedication and its attendant professional-

WEDNESDAY, JUNE 27, 1990
793
ism is recognized by the Bar and the public. Such dedicated service
makes the heavy workload of the Court much easier for each Member of
the Court.".

THURSDAY JUNE 28, 1990
795
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINIONS PER CURIAM
No. 88-421. Ashland Oil, Inc., Petitioner v. Herschel H. Rose, III,
etc., et al. Appeal from the Circuit Court of Kanawha County, West
Virginia. The motion of Committee on State Taxation of the Council of
State Chambers of Commerce for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae
is granted. The judgment is reversed and the case is remanded to the
Circuit Court for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion per curiam.
No. 89–337. National Mines Corporation, Petitioner v. Michael E.
Caryl, Tax Commissioner of the State of West Virginia. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the Circuit Court of Kanawha County, West Vir-
ginia. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is re-
versed and the case is remanded to the Circuit Court for further pro-
ceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per
curiam.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 89-628. Mountain States Legal Foundation, et al., Petitioners v.
National Wildlife Federation. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.
The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated
and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
District of Columbia Circuit for further consideration in light of Lujan
v. National Wildlife Federation, 497 U.S. (1990).
—
No. 89–1052. Three Buoys Houseboat Vacations U.S.A., Ltd., Peti-
tioner v. Harvey G. Morts, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. The petition for
writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit
for further consideration in light of Sisson v. Ruby, 497 U.S.
(1990).

796
THURSDAY JUNE 28. 1990
No. 89-1506. Joseph M. Gedan, et al., Petitioners v. Earle A.
Partington, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States.
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The petition for writ of certio-
rari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further
consideration in light of Cooter & Gell v. Hartmarx Corporation, 496
U.S. (1990).
No. 89–1697. Patrick M. O'Riley, Petitioner v. Union Oil Company of
California. On petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeal of
California, Second Appellate District. The petition for writ of certiorari
is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
Court of Appeal of California, Second Appellate District, for further
consideration in light of Tafflin v. Levitt, 493 U.S. — (1990). Justice
White, Justice Blackmun and Justice O'Connor dissent.
No. 89-1754. Texaco Refining and Marketing, Inc., et al., Petitioners
v. Estate of Dau Van Tran, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
Court of Appeals of Texas, Ninth District. The motion of Maritime Law
Association of the United States for leave to file a brief as amicus cu-
riae is granted. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the Court of Appeals of
Texas, Ninth District, for further consideration in light of Sisson v.
Ruby, 497 U.S. (1990). Justice Stevens dissents.

the case is remanded to the Court of Appeals of New York for further
consideration in light of Milkovich v. Lorain Journal Co., 497 U.S.
(1990).

On petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of North Caro-

and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is va-

(1990).

for the Eighth Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit for further consideration in
light of Idaho v. Wright, 497 U.S. (1990).

No. 89-7401. Paul A. Clarke, Petitioner v. West Virginia Board of
Regents, et al. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until July 19, 1990, within
which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a
petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice
Brennan, Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens, dis-
senting: For the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464
U.S. 928 (1983), we would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari with-
out reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.

No. 88-1553. Samuel A. Lewis, Director, Arizona Department of
Corrections, et al., Petitioners v. John Harvey Adamson. The motion of
respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit denied. The Chief Justice, Justice White and Justice
Scalia would grant the petition for a writ of certiorari, vacate the judg-
ment and remand the case to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit for further consideration in light of Walton v. Arizona,
497 U.S. (1990), Lewis v. Jeffers, 497 (1990) and Alabama v.
Smith, 490 U.S. (1989). Justice O'Connor and Justice Kennedy
took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion and this
petition.

No. A-929. Brian Karem, Applicant . Pat Priest, et al. The applica-

Court is denied. Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall would grant the

THURSDAY, JULY 12, 1990
817

MONDAY, JULY 23. 1990
825
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Marshall,
Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia,
and Justice Kennedy.
ASSIGNMENT ORDER
Pursuant to the provisions of Title 28 U.S.C. Section 42, it is ordered.
that the Chief Justice be, and he is hereby, assigned to the First Circuit
and the Third Circuit as Circuit Justice, effective July 20, 1990, pending
further order.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, AUGUST 7. 1990
829
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Marshall,
Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia,
and Justice Kennedy.
ORDER
Pursuant to the provisions of Title 28 U.S.C. Section 42, it is ordered.
that Justice Blackmun be, and he is hereby, assigned to the First Cir-
cuit as Circuit Justice, effective August 7, 1990, pending further order.
Pursuant to the provisions of Title 28 U.S.C. Section 42, it is ordered
that Justice Stevens be, and he is hereby, assigned to the Third Circuit
as Circuit Justice, effective August 7, 1990, pending further order.
It is further ordered that the order entered July 23, 1990, assigning
the Chief Justice to the First Circuit and to the Third Circuit as Circuit
Justice is vacated.

FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 21. 1990
917
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Marshall,
Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia
and Justice Kennedy.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-160. Mahmoud El-Abed Ahmad, Applicant v. George Wigen,
etc. The application for stay addressed to Justice Stevens and referred
to the Court is denied.
No. A-170. Djelos Ivezaj, Applicant v. Immigration and Naturaliza-
tion Service, et al. The application for stay of deportation addressed to
Justice Marshall and referred to the Court is denied.
No. D-854. In the Matter of Disbarment of Thomas J. McCallum.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-878. In the Matter of Disbarment of Jeffrey Mark Schwartz.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-894. In the Matter of Disbarment of Bernard Herbert Ostrow-
sky. Disbarment order entered.
No. D-900. In the Matter of Disbarment of John M. Skevin. Disbar-
ment order entered.
No. D-901. In the Matter of Disbarment of Bruce A. Olster. Disbar-
ment order entered.
No. D-906. In the Matter of Disbarment of Jonathan Erickson. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-912. In the Matter of Disbarment of Frederick Brockmeier,
IV. Disbarment order entered.
No. D-924. In the Matter of Disbarment of Charles Lionel Parker. It
is ordered that Charles Lionel Parker, of Akron, Ohio, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-925. In the Matter of Disbarment of H. J. M. Melaro. It is or-
dered that H. J. M. Melaro, of Silver Spring, Maryland, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-926. In the Matter of Disbarment of Willard Carlos McBride.
It is ordered that Willard Carlos McBride, of Hillcrest Heights, Mary-

land, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-927. In the Matter of Disbarment of Michael Isaacson. It is
ordered that Michael Isaacson, of Baltimore, Maryland, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-928. In the Matter of Disbarment of Michael Jennings Keady.
It is ordered that Michael Jennings Keady, of Palo Alto, California, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

is ordered that Robert E. Brimberry, of Brea, California, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-930. In the Matter of Disbarment of Donald L. Hobson. It is
ordered that Donald L. Hobson, of Detroit, Michigan, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-931. In the Matter of Disbarment of James P. Ryan. It is or-
dered that James P. Ryan, of Fort Lauderdale, Florida, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable.
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-932. In the Matter of Disbarment of Charles L. Bussey, Jr. It
is ordered that Charles L. Bussey, Jr., of St. Louis, Missouri, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-933. In the Matter of Disbarment of Arnold L. Ross. It is or-
dered that Arnold L. Ross, of Agoura Hills, California, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

ordered that Gregory F. Ireland, of Carmel, New York, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable.
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 90-348. New Era Publications International, ApS, Petitioner v.
Carol Publishing Group. The application for stay addressed to Justice
O'Connor and referred to the Court is denied.
No. 90-5723. James Steeley, Petitioner v. Alabama. The application
for stay addressed to Justice Scalia and referred to the Court is denied.
ASSIGNMENT ORDER
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Justice Pow-
ell (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit during the period of September 19
through September 20, 1990, and for such time as may be required to
complete unfinished business, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. Sec. 294(a), is or-
dered entered on the minutes of this Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. Sec.
295.
